If an object is a hardcover book, then it is printed text.\n5. If 1984 is a streaming service, then 1984 is a hardcover book.\n\nFrom premise 3, we know that if 1984 is a streaming service, then it must be digital media. However, premise 1 tells us that no digital media can be analog, and premise 2 states that every printed text is analog. \n\nLet's consider the possibility that 1984 is a streaming service:\n- If 1984 is a streaming service, then by premise 3, it must be digital media.\n- If 1984 is digital media, it cannot be analog (from premise 1).\n- If 1984 is analog (as it would be if it were a hardcover book, based on premise 4 and premise 5), then it cannot be digital media, which creates a contradiction.\n\nTherefore, the only way to avoid this contradiction is if 1984 is not a streaming service. If 1984 is not a streaming service, it does not need to be digital media, and thus it can be analog, which is consistent with it being a hardcover book (printed text).\n\nSince the premises do not allow 1984 to be both a streaming service and a hardcover book, and since the premises do not provide any other information that would support 1984 being a streaming service, we can conclude that 1984 is not a streaming service.\n</nl_cot>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (B).\n</answer>",

        "rationale": "Let:\n- D: An object is digital media.\n- A: An object is analog media.\n- P: An object is printed text.\n- S: An object is a streaming service.\n- H: An object is a hardcover book.\nPremises:\n1. No digital media are analog. (D \u2192 \u00acA)\n2. Every printed text is analog media. (P \u2192 A)\n3. All streaming services are digital media. (S \u2192 D)\n4. If an object is a hardcover book, then it is printed text. (H \u2192 P)\n5. If 1984 is a streaming service, then 1984 is a hardcover book. (S(1984) \u2192 H(1984))\n\nConclusion to Evaluate: \n1984 is not a streaming service. (\u00acS(1984))\n\nLogical Chain:\n- From premise 3, if 1984 is a streaming service, then 1984 is digital media (S(1984) \u2192 D(1984)).\n- From premise 1, if 1984 is digital media, then 1984 is not analog (D(1984) \u2192 \u00acA(1984)).\n- From premise 2, if 1984 is printed text, then 1984 is analog (P(1984) \u2192 A(1984)).\n- From premise 4, if 1984 is a hardcover book, then 1984 is printed text (H(1984) \u2192 P(1984)).\n- From premise 5, if 1984 is a streaming service, then 1984 is a hardcover book (S(1984) \u2192 H(1984)).\n\nAssuming 1984 is a streaming service:\n1. S(1984) \u2192 D(1984) (From premise 3)\n2. D(1984) \u2192 \u00acA(1984) (From premise 1)\n3. H(1984) \u2192 P(1984) (From premise 4)\n4. S(1984) \u2192 H(1984) (From premise 5)\n5. Combining 1 and 4: S(1984) \u2192 H(1984) \u2192 P(1984)\n6. From 2 and 5: S(1984) \u2192 H(1984) \u2192 P(1984) \u2192 \u00acA(1984)\n7. From 3 and 6: S(1984) \u2192 P(1984) \u2192 \u00acA(1984)\n\nThis leads to a contradiction because if 1984 is a streaming service (S(1984)), then 1984 must be analog (A(1984)), which contradicts the fact that digital media cannot be analog (D(1984) \u2192 \u00acA(1984)).\n\nTherefore, 1984 cannot be a streaming service.\n\nTruth Table (Key Possibilities):\n| S(1984) (Is 1984 a streaming service) | D(1984) (Is 1984 digital media) | A(1984) (Is 1984 analog) | H(1984) (Is 1984 a hardcover book) | P(1984) (Is 1984 printed text) |\n|---------------------------------------|---------------------------------|-------------------------|------------------------------------|--------------------------------|\n| True                                  | True                            | False                   | True                               | True                           |\n| False                                 | -                               | -                       | -                                  | -                              |\n\nGiven the logical chain, the only consistent scenario is that 1984 is not a streaming service.\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (A).\n</answer>",

since C is False, S = True\n    S = True\n    \u2192 From (8): U = True\nTruth Table (for T = True):\n| T (Thor is happy) | H (The Hulk is angry) | A (The Hulk wakes up) | B (A bridge is broken) | C (Peter Parker is a civilian) | S (Peter Parker is a superhero) | U (Peter Parker wears a uniform) |\n|-------------------|-----------------------|-----------------------|------------------------|---------------------------------|-----------------------------------|-----------------------------------|\n| True              | True                  | True                  | True                   | False                           | True                              | True                              |\n</truth_table>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (A).\n</answer>\n</EXAMPLE 1>\n\n<EXAMPLE 2>\n<premises>\nAll philosophers reason.\nSome sophists reason.\nAll who can reason can distinguish truth from falsehood.\nNobody who can distinguish truth from falsehood is morally perfect.\nThe theistic God is morally perfect.\nThe theistic God is a sophist.\n</premises>\n<conclusion>\nThe theistic God is a sophist and a philosopher.\n</conclusion>\n<question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? (P \u2192 R)\n    (Some sophists reason; does not force God to reason.)\n    If God reasons, then God can distinguish truth from falsehood. (R \u2192 D)\n    If God can distinguish truth from falsehood, then God is not morally perfect. (D \u2192 \u00acM)\n    God is morally perfect. (M is True)\n    God is a sophist. (S is True)\nLogical chain:\n    From (5) M = True.\n    From (4), if D were True then M would be False; therefore, D must be False.\n    From (3), if R were True then D would be True; therefore, R must be False.\n    From (1), if P were True then R would be True; therefore, P must be False.\n    Given (6), S = True.\nTruth Table (for god):\n| P (Philosopher) | R (Reasons) | D (Distinguishes truth) | M (Morally Perfect) | S (Sophist) | S \u2227 P (Sophist and Philosopher) |\n|-----------------|-------------|-------------------------|---------------------|-------------|---------------------------------|\n| False           | False       | False                   | True                | True        | False                           |\n</truth_table>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (B).\n</answer>\n</EXAMPLE 2>\n\n<EXAMPLE 3>\n<premises>\nWilliam Dickinson was a British politician who sat in the House of Commons William Dickinson attended Westminster school for high school and then the University of Edinburgh. \nThe University of Edinburgh is a university located in the United Kingdom. \nWilliam Dickinson supported the Portland Whigs. \nPeople who supported the Portland Whigs did not get a seat in the Parliament.\n</premises>\n<conclusion>\nWilliam Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university.\n</conclusion>\n<question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? Since Spanish is a Romance language (Premise 4), and all Romance languages are related to each other (Premise 3), it means German is indirectly related to all Romance languages.\n- However, to be a Romance language, German must be directly related to another Romance language within the same language family, and it must also be an Indo-European language (Premise 1).\n\nSince Premise 5 only states that German is related to Spanish and does not explicitly state that German is a Romance language or an Indo-European language, we cannot definitively conclude that German is a Romance language based solely on the given premises.\n\nTherefore, the information provided is not sufficient to confirm or deny whether German is a Romance language.\n</nl_cot>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (C).\n</answer>",

A city can only be in one state in the U.S., except for Bristol, Texarkana, Texhoma, and Union City.\n\nFrom premise 4, we know St Pierre is not in Montana. From premise 3, Butte is in Montana. Premise 5 tells us that no city in Butte can be in St Pierre. Since Butte is in Montana, St Pierre is not in Montana. \n\nPremise 6 states that generally, a city can only be in one state in the U.S., except for specific cities (Bristol, Texarkana, Texhoma, and Union City).         "premises": "All Brown Swiss cattle are cows.\nSome pets are Brown Swiss Cattle.\nAll cows are domesticated animals.\nAlligators are not domesticated animals.\nTed is an alligator.",
        "conclusions": "Ted is a pet.",
        "rationale": "Let:\n    B: Ted is a Brown Swiss cattle.\n    P: Ted is a pet.\n    C: Ted is a cow.\n    A: Ted is an alligator.\n    D: Ted is a domesticated animal.\nPremises:\n    1. All Brown Swiss cattle are cows. (B \u2192 C)\n    2. Some pets are Brown Swiss Cattle. (P \u2229 B \u2260 \u2205)\n    3. All cows are domesticated animals. (C \u2192 D)\n    4. Alligators are not domesticated animals. (A \u2192 \u00acD)\n    5. Ted is an alligator. (A = True)\nLogical Chain:\n    From (4) and (5), we have:\n        A = True\n        A \u2192 \u00acD\n        Therefore, D = False (Ted is not a domesticated animal).\n    From (3) and the fact that D = False, we know:\n        Since all cows are domesticated animals and D is False, Ted cannot be a cow (C = False).\n    From (1) and the fact that Ted is an alligator (A = True), we know:\n        B \u2192 C\n        Since C = False, B must also be False (Ted is not a Brown Swiss cattle).\n    From (2) and the fact that B = False, we know:\n        P \u2229 B \u2260 \u2205\n        Since B = False, it implies that there is no overlap between pets and Brown Swiss cattle, and therefore, Ted cannot be a pet.\nTruth Table (Key Possibilities):\n| A (Ted is an alligator) | B (Ted is a Brown Swiss cattle) | C (Ted is a cow) | P (Ted is a pet) | D (Ted is a domesticated animal) |\n|------------------------|--------------------------------|------------------|------------------|---------------------------------|\n| True                   | False                          | False            | False            | False                           |\n</truth_table>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (B).\n</answer>",

Alligators are not domesticated animals.\n5. Ted is an alligator.\n\nFrom these premises, we can infer the following:\n\n- Since all Brown Swiss cattle are cows (Premise 1), and all cows are domesticated animals (Premise 3), it follows that all Brown Swiss cattle are domesticated animals.\n- Since Ted is an alligator (Premise 5), and alligators are not domesticated animals (Premise 4), it follows that Ted is not a Brown Swiss cattle (because all Brown Swiss cattle are domesticated, and Ted is not domesticated).\n- Since some pets are Brown Swiss Cattle (Premise 2), it means that there exists at least one pet that is a Brown Swiss cattle, but this does not affect the conclusion about Ted.\n\nNow, let's consider the conclusion: \"If Ted is a Brown Swiss cattle, then Ted is not a pet.\"\n\nSince we have established that Ted is an alligator and alligators are not domesticated animals, and all Brown Swiss cattle are domesticated, it follows that Ted cannot be a Brown Swiss cattle. Therefore, the antecedent of the conditional statement is false. In logic, a statement of the form \"If P, then Q\" is true if P is false, regardless of the truth value of Q. Thus, the conclusion \"If Ted is a Brown Swiss cattle, then Ted is not a pet\" is true.\n\n</nl_cot>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (A).\n</answer>",

(R \u2192 D)\n    If God can distinguish truth from falsehood, then God is not morally perfect. (D \u2192 \u00acM)\n    God is morally perfect. (M is True)\n    God is a sophist. All mature stocks are suitable for a retirement fund.\n5. KO is a mature stock.\n\nFrom premise 4, we know that if a stock is mature, it is suitable for a retirement fund. Premise 5 states that KO is a mature stock, so by premise 4, KO must be suitable for a retirement fund.\n\nPremise 2 states that if a stock is bought to earn profits from rapid price appreciation, then it is not suitable for a retirement fund. This means that if a stock is suitable for a retirement fund, it cannot be bought to earn profits from rapid price appreciation.\n\nPremise 1 tells us that all growth stocks are bought to earn profits from rapid price appreciation. Therefore, if a stock is a growth stock, it is not suitable for a retirement fund.\n\nSince KO is suitable for a retirement fund (from premise 4 and premise 5), and it cannot be a growth stock (because it would not be suitable for a retirement fund), KO cannot be a growth stock.\n\nPremise 3 states that some stocks are growth stocks. This does not provide any information about KO being a growth stock or not, but it confirms that there are growth stocks.\n\nThe key point is that KO, being a mature stock and suitable for a retirement fund, cannot be a growth stock. However, the question asks if KO is a stock. From the premises, we can logically infer that KO must be a stock because it is specifically mentioned as a mature stock, and all mature stocks are a subset of stocks.         "premises": "All growth stocks are bought to earn profits from rapid price appreciation.\nIf the stock price is bought to earn profits from rapid price appreciation, then it is not suitable for a retirement fund.\nSome stocks are growth stocks.\nAll mature stocks are suitable for a retirement fund.\nKO is a mature stock.",

        "rationale": "<nl_cot>\nLet's analyze the premises step by step:\n\n1. **All growth stocks are bought to earn profits from rapid price appreciation.**\n   - This means if a stock is a growth stock, then it is bought with the intention of profiting from its rapid price appreciation.\n\n2. **If the stock price is bought to earn profits from rapid price appreciation, then it is not suitable for a retirement fund.**\n   - This means that any stock bought for rapid price appreciation is unsuitable for a retirement fund.\n\n3. **Some stocks are growth stocks.**\n   - This means there exists at least one stock that is a growth stock.\n\n4. **All mature stocks are suitable for a retirement fund.**\n   - This means if a stock is a mature stock, then it is suitable for a retirement fund.\n\n5. **KO is a mature stock.**\n   - This means KO is suitable for a retirement fund.\n\nNow, let's consider the conclusion: \"KO is a stock and a growth stock.\"\n\n- If KO is a mature stock, then from premise 4, KO is suitable for a retirement fund.\n- If KO were a growth stock, then from premise 2, it would not be suitable for a retirement fund, which contradicts the fact that KO is suitable for a retirement fund (premise 5).\n\nTherefore, KO cannot be a growth stock because it would make it unsuitable for a retirement fund, which contradicts the information that KO is suitable for a retirement fund.\n</nl_cot>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (B).\n</answer>",

If the stock price is bought to earn profits from rapid price appreciation, then it is not suitable for a retirement fund.\n3. Some stocks are growth stocks.\n4. All mature stocks are suitable for a retirement fund.\n5. KO is a mature stock.\n\nFrom these premises, we can derive the following:\n- Since KO is a mature stock (premise 5), and all mature stocks are suitable for a retirement fund (premise 4), KO is suitable for a retirement fund.\n- According to premise 2, if a stock is bought to earn profits from rapid price appreciation, it is not suitable for a retirement fund. Since KO is suitable for a retirement fund, KO cannot be bought to earn profits from rapid price appreciation.\n- Since all growth stocks are bought to earn profits from rapid price appreciation (premise 1), KO cannot be a growth stock.\n\nNow, let's analyze the conclusion:\n\"If KO is a growth stock or bought to earn profits from rapid price appreciation, then KO is neither a stock nor is its price volatile.\"\n\nFrom our deductions:\n- KO cannot be a growth stock.\n- KO cannot be bought to earn profits from rapid price appreciation.\n\nTherefore, the condition \"KO is a growth stock or bought to earn profits from rapid price appreciation\" is false. A false condition implies anything, including the conclusion that KO is neither a stock nor its price is volatile.         "rationale": "Let:\n- J: Joe's vehicle registration plate begins with the number 34.\n- T: Tom's license plate begins with the number 35.\n- I: A plate is from Istanbul.\nPremises:\n1. All vehicle registration plates in Istanbul begin with the number 34. (If a plate is from Istanbul, then it begins with 34. I \u2192 J)\n2. Plates that do not begin with the number 34 are not from Istanbul. (If a plate does not begin with 34, then it is not from Istanbul. \u00acJ \u2192 \u00acI)\n3. Joe's vehicle registration plate is from Istanbul. (I is True for Joe's plate)\n4. Tom's license plate begins with the number 35. (T is True)\n5. If a license plate begins with the number 35, then it does not begin with the number 34. (T \u2192 \u00acJ)\n\nLogical chain:\n- From premise 3, I is True for Joe's plate.\n- From premise 1, since I is True, J must be True (a plate from Istanbul begins with 34).\n- Tom's plate (T) is True, and from premise 5, T \u2192 \u00acJ. All vehicle registration plates in Istanbul begin with the number 34. (\u2200x(I(x) \u2192 B34(x)))\n2. Plates that do not begin with the number 34 are not from Istanbul. (\u00acB34(x) \u2192 \u00acI(x))\n3. Joe's vehicle registration plate is from Istanbul. (I(Joe))\n4. Tom's license plate begins with the number 35. (B35(Tom))\n5. If a license plate begins with the number 35, then it does not begin with the number 34. (B35(x) \u2192 \u00acB34(x))\n\nLogical chain:\n- From premise 4, we know B35(Tom).\n- From premise 5, we can infer \u00acB34(Tom) (if Tom's plate begins with 35, it cannot begin with 34).\n- From premise 2, we know \u00acB34(x) \u2192 \u00acI(x).         "premises": "If people at Mary's school work in student jobs on campus, then they need to earn money to help pay for their college tuition.\nIf people at Mary's school order takeout frequently in college, then they work in student jobs on campus.\nPeople at Mary's school order takeout frequently in college or enjoy the dining hall meals and recipes.\nIf people at Mary's school enjoy the dining hall meals and recipes, then they are not picky eaters.\nIf people at Mary's school enjoy the dining hall meals and recipes, then they spend a lot of their time eating and catching up with friends in the campus dining halls.\nHannah is at Mary's school.\nHannah works in student jobs on campus and if she needs to earn money to help pay for her college tuition, then she is neither picky nor needs to earn money to help pay for her college tuition.",
        "conclusions": "Hannah is at Mary's school and she is not a picky eater and spends a lot of her time eating and catching up with friends in the campus dining halls.",
        "rationale": "<nl_cot>\nLet's analyze the premises step by step to determine if the conclusion logically follows:\n\n1. **Premise 1**: If people at Mary's school work in student jobs on campus, then they need to earn money to help pay for their college tuition.\n   - \\( S \\rightarrow M \\) where \\( S \\) is working in student jobs on campus and \\( M \\) is needing to earn money to help pay for college tuition.\n\n2. **Premise 2**: If people at Mary's school order takeout frequently in college, then they work in student jobs on campus.\n   - \\( T \\rightarrow S \\) where \\( T \\) is ordering takeout frequently.\n\n3. **Premise 3**: People at Mary's school order takeout frequently in college or enjoy the dining hall meals and recipes.\n   - \\( T \\lor D \\) where \\( D \\) is enjoying the dining hall meals and recipes.\n\n4. **Premise 4**: If people at Mary's school enjoy the dining hall meals and recipes, then they are not picky eaters.\n   - \\( D \\rightarrow \\neg P \\) where \\( P \\) is being a picky eater.\n\n5. **Premise 5**: If people at Mary's school enjoy the dining hall meals and recipes, then they spend a lot of their time eating and catching up with friends in the campus dining halls.\n   - \\( D \\rightarrow E \\) where \\( E \\) is spending a lot of time eating and catching up with friends in the campus dining halls.\n\n6. **Premise 6**: Hannah is at Mary's school.\n   - \\( H \\) where \\( H \\) is Hannah being at Mary's school.\n\n7. **Premise 7**: Hannah works in student jobs on campus and if she needs to earn money to help pay for her college tuition, then she is neither picky nor needs to earn money to help pay for her college tuition.\n   - \\( S_H \\land (M_H \\rightarrow \\neg P_H \\land \\neg M_H) \\) where \\( S_H \\) is Hannah working in student jobs, \\( M_H \\) is needing to earn money, and \\( P_H \\) is being a picky eater.\n\nNow, let's break down the premises and see if we can derive the conclusion:\n\n- From Premise 6, we know \\( H \\) is true.\n- From Premise 7, we know \\( S_H \\) is true. According to Premise 1, \\( S_H \\rightarrow M_H \\) is true. So \\( M_H \\) is true.\n- Since \\( M_H \\) is true, according to Premise 7, \\( \\neg P_H \\) must be true (Hannah is not a picky eater).\n- Since \\( M_H \\) is true, according to Premise 1, \\( S_H \\) must be true, which is consistent with Premise 7.\n- Now, we need to check the second part of Premise 7: \\( M_H \\rightarrow \\neg M_H \\land \\neg M_H \\). This is a contradiction, so \\( M_H \\) must be false. This is consistent with \\( M_H \\rightarrow \\neg P_H \\land \\neg M_H \\) because if \\( M_H \\) is false, the implication is true regardless of the truth value of \\( \\neg P_H \\land \\neg M_H \\).\n\nSince \\( M_H \\) is false, Hannah does not need to earn money to help pay for her college tuition, and according to Premise 4, if \\( D_H \\) is true, then \\( \\neg P_H \\) is true, which we already know from Premise 7. According to Premise 5, if \\( D_H \\) is true, then \\( E_H \\) is true. However, we do not have information to determine whether \\( D_H \\) is true or false.\n\nTherefore, we can conclude that Hannah is at Mary's school and she is not a picky eater, but we cannot definitively conclude that she spends a lot of her time eating and catching up with friends in the campus dining halls because we do not have enough information to determine \\( D_H \\).\n</nl_cot>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (C).\n</answer>",

since C is False, S = True\n    S = True\n    \u2192 From (8): U = True\nTruth Table (for T = True):\n| T (Thor is happy) | H (The Hulk is angry) | A (The Hulk wakes up) | B (A bridge is broken) | C (Peter Parker is a civilian) | S (Peter Parker is a superhero) | U (Peter Parker wears a uniform) |\n|-------------------|-----------------------|-----------------------|------------------------|---------------------------------|-----------------------------------|-----------------------------------|\n| True              | True                  | True                  | True                   | False                           | True                              | True                              |\n</truth_table>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (A).\n</answer>\n</EXAMPLE 1>\n\n<EXAMPLE 2>\n<premises>\nAll philosophers reason.\nSome sophists reason.\nAll who can reason can distinguish truth from falsehood.\nNobody who can distinguish truth from falsehood is morally perfect.\nThe theistic God is morally perfect.\nThe theistic God is a sophist.\n</premises>\n<conclusion>\nThe theistic God is a sophist and a philosopher.\n</conclusion>\n<question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? The theistic God is a sophist and a philosopher.\n</question>\n<options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</options>\n<truth_table>\nLet:\n    P: God is a philosopher\n    R: God reasons\n    D: God can distinguish truth from falsehood\n    M: God is morally perfect\n    S: God is a sophist\nPremises for God:\n    If God is a philosopher, then God reasons. (P \u2192 R)\n    (Some sophists reason; does not force God to reason.)\n    If God reasons, then God can distinguish truth from falsehood. (R \u2192 D)\n    If God can distinguish truth from falsehood, then God is not morally perfect. (D \u2192 \u00acM)\n    God is morally perfect. (M is True)\n    God is a sophist. (S is True)\nLogical chain:\n    From (5) M = True.\n    From (4), if D were True then M would be False; therefore, D must be False.\n    From (3), if R were True then D would be True; therefore, R must be False.\n    From (1), if P were True then R would be True; therefore, P must be False.\n    Given (6), S = True.\nTruth Table (for god):\n| P (Philosopher) | R (Reasons) | D (Distinguishes truth) | M (Morally Perfect) | S (Sophist) | S \u2227 P (Sophist and Philosopher) |\n|-----------------|-------------|-------------------------|---------------------|-------------|---------------------------------|\n| False           | False       | False                   | True                | True        | False                           |\n</truth_table>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (B).\n</answer>\n</EXAMPLE 2>\n\n<EXAMPLE 3>\n<premises>\nWilliam Dickinson was a British politician who sat in the House of Commons William Dickinson attended Westminster school for high school and then the University of Edinburgh. \nThe University of Edinburgh is a university located in the United Kingdom. \nWilliam Dickinson supported the Portland Whigs. \nPeople who supported the Portland Whigs did not get a seat in the Parliament.\n</premises>\n<conclusion>\nWilliam Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university.\n</conclusion>\n<question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? William Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university.\n</question> \n<options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</options>\n<truth_table>\nLet:\n    W: William Dickinson attended Westminster School for high school.\n    E: William Dickinson attended the University of Edinburgh.\n    U: The University of Edinburgh is located in the United Kingdom (Given explicitly, so U = True).\n    L: Westminster School is located in the United Kingdom (Not explicitly stated; uncertain).\nPremises:\n    William Dickinson attended Westminster School for high school and then the University of Edinburgh.\n    The University of Edinburgh is a university located in the United Kingdom.\n    William Dickinson supported the Portland Whigs.\n    People who supported the Portland Whigs did not get a seat in the Parliament.\nConclusion to Evaluate: \n    William Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university, which translates to L \u2227 U.\nLogical Chain:\n    From (2), we know U = True.\n    However, L is not explicitly given by the premises; although implied by context, it remains uncertain.\n    Therefore, since U = True but L is uncertain, the conjunction L \u2227 U is uncertain.\nTruth Table (Key Possibilities):\n| L (Westminster School in UK) | U (University of Edinburgh in UK) | L \u2227 U (Both in UK) |\n|------------------------------|------------------------------------|--------------------|\n| True                         | True                               | True               |\n| False                        | True                               | False              |\n</truth_table>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (C).\n</answer>\n</EXAMPLE 3>\n\n\nThe following is the problem you need to solve.\n\n<premises>\nIf people at Mary's school work in student jobs on campus, then they need to earn money to help pay for their college tuition.\nIf people at Mary's school order takeout frequently in college, then they work in student jobs on campus.\nPeople at Mary's school order takeout frequently in college or enjoy the dining hall meals and recipes.\nIf people at Mary's school enjoy the dining hall meals and recipes, then they are not picky eaters.\nIf people at Mary's school enjoy the dining hall meals and recipes, then they spend a lot of their time eating and catching up with friends in the campus dining halls.\nHannah is at Mary's school.\nHannah works in student jobs on campus and if she needs to earn money to help pay for her college tuition, then she is neither picky nor needs to earn money to help pay for her college tuition.\n</premises>\n<conclusion>\nHannah is at Mary's school and she is not a picky eater and spends a lot of her time eating and catching up with friends in the campus dining halls.\n</conclusion>\n<question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain?     {
        "premises": "If people at Mary's school work in student jobs on campus, then they need to earn money to help pay for their college tuition.\nIf people at Mary's school order takeout frequently in college, then they work in student jobs on campus.\nPeople at Mary's school order takeout frequently in college or enjoy the dining hall meals and recipes.\nIf people at Mary's school enjoy the dining hall meals and recipes, then they are not picky eaters.\nIf people at Mary's school enjoy the dining hall meals and recipes, then they spend a lot of their time eating and catching up with friends in the campus dining halls.\nHannah is at Mary's school.\nHannah works in student jobs on campus and if she needs to earn money to help pay for her college tuition, then she is neither picky nor needs to earn money to help pay for her college tuition.",
        "conclusions": "Hannah is at Mary's school and she either is not a picky eater or, if she is, then she spends a lot of her time eating and catching up with friends in the campus dining halls.",
        "rationale": "<nl_cot>\nLet's analyze the premises and the conclusion step by step:\n\n1. If people at Mary's school work in student jobs on campus, then they need to earn money to help pay for their college tuition. (P \u2192 Q)\n2. If people at Mary's school order takeout frequently in college, then they work in student jobs on campus. (R \u2192 P)\n3. People at Mary's school order takeout frequently in college or enjoy the dining hall meals and recipes. (R \u2228 S)\n4. If people at Mary's school enjoy the dining hall meals and recipes, then they are not picky eaters. (S \u2192 T)\n5. If people at Mary's school enjoy the dining hall meals and recipes, then they spend a lot of their time eating and catching up with friends in the campus dining halls. (S \u2192 U)\n6. Hannah is at Mary's school. (H)\n7. Hannah works in student jobs on campus and if she needs to earn money to help pay for her college tuition, then she is neither picky nor needs to earn money to help pay for her college tuition. (P \u2227 (Q \u2192 V))\n\nNow, let's break down the conclusion:\n- Hannah is at Mary's school (H)\n- She either is not a picky eater (\u00acT) or, if she is, then she spends a lot of her time eating and catching up with friends in the campus dining halls (T \u2192 U)\n\nFrom premise 7, we know that Hannah works in student jobs on campus (P). According to premise 1, if people at Mary's school work in student jobs on campus, then they need to earn money to help pay for their college tuition (Q). This means Q is true for Hannah.\n\nFrom premise 7, we also know that if she needs to earn money to help pay for her college tuition (Q), then she is neither picky (\u00acT) nor needs to earn money to help pay for her college tuition (V). Since Q is true, V must be false, which means T must be false (Hannah is a picky eater).\n\nNow, we need to check the second part of the conclusion: if she is a picky eater (T), then she spends a lot of her time eating and catching up with friends in the campus dining halls (T \u2192 U). Since T is true, for the implication T \u2192 U to be true, U must also be true (she spends a lot of her time eating and catching up with friends in the campus dining halls).\n\nWe need to check if this is consistent with the premises. Since Hannah works in student jobs on campus (P), according to premise 2, if people at Mary's school order takeout frequently in college, then they work in student jobs on campus (R \u2192 P). This means R must be false (people at Mary's school do not order takeout frequently in college).\n\nFrom premise 3, if people at Mary's school order takeout frequently in college or enjoy the dining hall meals and recipes (R \u2228 S), and since R is false, S must be true (people at Mary's school enjoy the dining hall meals and recipes). According to premise 4, if people at Mary's school enjoy the dining hall meals and recipes, then they are not picky eaters (S \u2192 T). However, we already established that T is true (Hannah is a picky eater), which contradicts S \u2192 T. Therefore, the assumption that S is true leads to a contradiction.\n\nSince S must be false (people at Mary's school do not enjoy the dining hall meals and recipes), and S \u2192 U is a true statement (if S is false, U can be either true or false), U can be true or false. This means the second part of the conclusion (T \u2192 U) is true regardless of the value of U.\n\nTherefore, the conclusion is consistent with the premises.\n</nl_cot>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (A).\n</answer>",
        "label": "False",
        "predict": "True",

However, dried Thai chilies being spicy does not directly imply they are products of Baked by Melissa. \n\nFrom premise 4, we know that products from Baked by Melissa are cupcakes, and since all cupcakes are baked sweets, dried Thai chilies cannot be products from Baked by Melissa because they are not baked sweets.\n\nTherefore, the statement \"Dried Thai chilies are products of Baked by Melissa\" is false based on the given premises.\n</nl_cot>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (B).\n</answer>",

All products from Baked by Melissa are cupcakes.\n5. Dried Thai chilies are spicy or mala hotpots or not baked sweets.\n\nFrom premise 4, we know that any product from Baked by Melissa is a cupcake. Since all cupcakes are baked sweets (premise 2), any product from Baked by Melissa is a baked sweet.\n\nFrom premise 1, no baked sweets are spicy. Therefore, any product from Baked by Melissa (which is a baked sweet) cannot be spicy.\n\nPremise 5 states that dried Thai chilies are spicy or mala hotpots or not baked sweets. Since we know that dried Thai chilies are not spicy (because they cannot be from Baked by Melissa, and all mala hotpots are spicy), the only way premise 5 can hold true is if dried Thai chilies are either mala hotpots or not baked sweets.\n\nIf dried Thai chilies were mala hotpots, they would be spicy, which contradicts the fact that dried Thai chilies are not spicy. Therefore, dried Thai chilies must be not baked sweets.\n\nSince dried Thai chilies are not baked sweets, they do not fall under the category of products from Baked by Melissa.\n</nl_cot>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (A).\n</answer>",

The theistic God is a sophist and a philosopher.\n</question>\n<options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</options>\n<truth_table>\nLet:\n    P: God is a philosopher\n    R: God reasons\n    D: God can distinguish truth from falsehood\n    M: God is morally perfect\n    S: God is a sophist\nPremises for God:\n    If God is a philosopher, then God reasons. (P \u2192 R)\n    (Some sophists reason; does not force God to reason.)\n    If God reasons, then God can distinguish truth from falsehood. (R \u2192 D)\n    If God can distinguish truth from falsehood, then God is not morally perfect. (D \u2192 \u00acM)\n    God is morally perfect. (M is True)\n    God is a sophist. (S is True)\nLogical chain:\n    From (5) M = True.\n    From (4), if D were True then M would be False; therefore, D must be False.\n    From (3), if R were True then D would be True; therefore, R must be False.\n    From (1), if P were True then R would be True; therefore, P must be False.\n    Given (6), S = True.\nTruth Table (for god):\n| P (Philosopher) | R (Reasons) | D (Distinguishes truth) | M (Morally Perfect) | S (Sophist) | S \u2227 P (Sophist and Philosopher) |\n|-----------------|-------------|-------------------------|---------------------|-------------|---------------------------------|\n| False           | False       | False                   | True                | True        | False                           |\n</truth_table>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (B).\n</answer>\n</EXAMPLE 2>\n\n<EXAMPLE 3>\n<premises>\nWilliam Dickinson was a British politician who sat in the House of Commons William Dickinson attended Westminster school for high school and then the University of Edinburgh. \nThe University of Edinburgh is a university located in the United Kingdom. \nWilliam Dickinson supported the Portland Whigs. \nPeople who supported the Portland Whigs did not get a seat in the Parliament.\n</premises>\n<conclusion>\nWilliam Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university.\n</conclusion>\n<question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? No baked sweets are spicy. (\u00acB \u2192 \u00acS)\n    2. All cupcakes are baked sweets. (C \u2192 B)\n    3. All mala hotpots are spicy. (M \u2192 S)\n    4. All products from Baked by Melissa are cupcakes. (Baked by Melissa \u2192 C)\n    5. Dried Thai chilies are spicy or mala hotpots or not baked sweets. (D \u2192 S \u2228 M \u2228 \u00acB)\n\nConclusion to Evaluate:\n    D is a mala hotpot (D \u2192 M)\n\nLogical Chain:\n    From (1) and (5), we have:\n    (D \u2192 S \u2228 M \u2228 \u00acB)\n    Since (1) states that no baked sweets are spicy (\u00acB \u2192 \u00acS), we can infer:\n    (D \u2192 M \u2228 \u00acB) (By eliminating S from the disjunction in (5))\n    From (2), all cupcakes are baked sweets (C \u2192 B), so:\n    (D \u2192 \u00acB) (Since D is not a cupcake, it cannot be a baked sweet)\n    Given (D \u2192 \u00acB) and (D \u2192 M \u2228 \u00acB), we can infer:\n    (D \u2192 M) (By modus ponens)\n\nTruth Table (Key Possibilities):\n| D (Dried Thai chilies) | B (Baked sweet) | S (Spicy) | M (Malah hotpot) | D \u2192 M (Dried Thai chilies are mala hotpot) |\n|------------------------|-----------------|-----------|------------------|-------------------------------------------|\n| True                   | False           | True      | True             | True                                      |\n| True                   | False           | False     | True             | True                                      |\n| True                   | True            | True      | True             | True                                      |\n| True                   | True            | False     | True             | True                                      |\n| False                  | -               | -        | -                | -                                         |\n\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (A).\n</answer>",

        "premises": "No baked sweets are spicy.\nAll cupcakes are baked sweets.\nAll mala hotpots are spicy.\nAll products from Baked by Melissa are cupcakes.\nDried Thai chilies are spicy or mala hotpots or not baked sweets.",
        "conclusions": "Dried Thai chilies are neither products of Baked by Melissa nor baked sweets.",
        "rationale": "Let:\n    S: The item is a baked sweet.\n    C: The item is a cupcake.\n    M: The item is a mala hotpot.\n    B: The item is a product from Baked by Melissa.\n    D: The item is a dried Thai chili.\nPremises:\n    \u00ac(S \u2227 D) (No baked sweets are spicy, so dried Thai chilies are not baked sweets).\n    C \u2192 S (All cupcakes are baked sweets).\n    M \u2192 D (All mala hotpots are spicy, and dried Thai chilies are either mala hotpots, or spicy, or not baked sweets).\n    B \u2192 C (All products from Baked by Melissa are cupcakes).\n    D \u2192 (M \u2228 \u00acS \u2228 \u00acS) (Dried Thai chilies are spicy or mala hotpots or not baked sweets, and since no baked sweets are spicy, it simplifies to D \u2192 (M \u2228 \u00acS)).\n\nLogical chain:\n1. From (1), D is not a baked sweet (\u00acS \u2227 D is false, so D \u2192 \u00acS).\n2. From (5), since D is a dried Thai chili, it must fit the condition D \u2192 (M \u2228 \u00acS). Given \u00acS is true from (1), D \u2192 (M \u2228 \u00acS) simplifies to D \u2192 M.\n3. From (3), M is true if D is a mala hotpot. Since D \u2192 M, if D is a dried Thai chili, it must be a mala hotpot.\n4. From (4), if D is a mala hotpot, then B must be false (since B \u2192 C, and C is a baked sweet, which contradicts M being a mala hotpot, which is spicy).\n\nTruth Table (for D):\n| D (Dried Thai Chili) | S (Baked Sweet) | C (Cupcake) | M (Mala Hotpot) | B (Baked by Melissa) |\n|----------------------|-----------------|-------------|-----------------|---------------------|\n| True                 | False           | True        | True            | False               |\n</truth_table>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (A).\n</answer>",

(P \u2192 R)\n    (Some sophists reason; does not force God to reason.)\n    If God reasons, then God can distinguish truth from falsehood. (R \u2192 D)\n    If God can distinguish truth from falsehood, then God is not morally perfect. (D \u2192 \u00acM)\n    God is morally perfect. (M is True)\n    God is a sophist. (S is True)\nLogical chain:\n    From (5) M = True.\n    From (4), if D were True then M would be False; therefore, D must be False.\n    From (3), if R were True then D would be True; therefore, R must be False.\n    From (1), if P were True then R would be True; therefore, P must be False.\n    Given (6), S = True.\nTruth Table (for god):\n| P (Philosopher) | R (Reasons) | D (Distinguishes truth) | M (Morally Perfect) | S (Sophist) | S \u2227 P (Sophist and Philosopher) |\n|-----------------|-------------|-------------------------|---------------------|-------------|---------------------------------|\n| False           | False       | False                   | True                | True        | False                           |\n</truth_table>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (B).\n</answer>\n</EXAMPLE 2>\n\n<EXAMPLE 3>\n<premises>\nWilliam Dickinson was a British politician who sat in the House of Commons William Dickinson attended Westminster school for high school and then the University of Edinburgh. \nThe University of Edinburgh is a university located in the United Kingdom. \nWilliam Dickinson supported the Portland Whigs. \nPeople who supported the Portland Whigs did not get a seat in the Parliament.\n</premises>\n<conclusion>\nWilliam Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university.\n</conclusion>\n<question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? William Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university.\n</question> \n<options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</options>\n<truth_table>\nLet:\n    W: William Dickinson attended Westminster School for high school.\n    E: William Dickinson attended the University of Edinburgh.\n    U: The University of Edinburgh is located in the United Kingdom (Given explicitly, so U = True).\n    L: Westminster School is located in the United Kingdom (Not explicitly stated; uncertain).\nPremises:\n    William Dickinson attended Westminster School for high school and then the University of Edinburgh.\n    The University of Edinburgh is a university located in the United Kingdom.\n    William Dickinson supported the Portland Whigs.\n    People who supported the Portland Whigs did not get a seat in the Parliament.\nConclusion to Evaluate: \n    William Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university, which translates to L \u2227 U.\nLogical Chain:\n    From (2), we know U = True.\n    However, L is not explicitly given by the premises;         "rationale": "<nl_cot>\nLet's analyze the premises step-by-step to determine if the conclusion logically follows.\n\n1. **Premise 1**: If a restaurant is listed in Yelp\u2019s recommendations, then the restaurant has not received many negative reviews.\n   - \\( L \\rightarrow \\neg N \\)\n   where \\( L \\) is the restaurant being listed in Yelp\u2019s recommendations, and \\( N \\) is the restaurant receiving many negative reviews.\n\n2. **Premise 2**: All restaurants with a rating greater than four are listed in Yelp\u2019s recommendations.\n   - \\( R > 4 \\rightarrow L \\)\n   where \\( R > 4 \\) is the restaurant having a rating greater than four.\n\n3. **Premise 3**: Some restaurants that do not provide take-out service receive many negative reviews.\n   - \\( \\exists x (T(x) \\rightarrow N(x)) \\)\n   where \\( T(x) \\) is the restaurant not providing take-out service.\n\n4. **Premise 4**: All restaurants that are popular among local residents have ratings greater than four.\n   - \\( P \\rightarrow R > 4 \\)\n   where \\( P \\) is the restaurant being popular among local residents.\n\n5. **Premise 5**: The Hamden Plaza Subway store has a rating greater than four, or it is popular among local residents.\n   - \\( R > 4 \\lor P \\)\n\nNow, we need to check the conclusion:\n- If the Hamden Plaza Subway store provides take-out service and receives many negative reviews, then its rating is greater than 4 and it does not provide take-out service.\n\nLet's denote the Hamden Plaza Subway store as \\( H \\):\n- \\( T(H) \\) is the store providing take-out service.\n- \\( N(H) \\) is the store receiving many negative reviews.\n\nThe conclusion can be written as:\n- \\( T(H) \\land N(H) \\rightarrow (R > 4 \\land \\neg T(H)) \\)\n\nWe need to see if this logically follows from the premises.\n\nFrom Premise 5, we have:\n- \\( R > 4 \\lor P \\)\n\nFrom Premise 2, if \\( R > 4 \\), then \\( H \\) is listed in Yelp\u2019s recommendations:\n- \\( R > 4 \\rightarrow \\neg N(H) \\)\n\nFrom Premise 1, if \\( H \\) is listed in Yelp\u2019s recommendations, then \\( H \\) does not receive many negative reviews:\n- \\( L \\rightarrow \\neg N(H) \\)\n\nGiven \\( N(H) \\) (the store receives many negative reviews), we can infer:\n- \\( R > 4 \\) cannot be true because if \\( R > 4 \\), then \\( \\neg N(H) \\) would be true, which contradicts \\( N(H) \\).\n\nTherefore, \\( P \\) (the store is popular among local residents) must be true:\n- \\( P \\) is true.\n\nFrom Premise 4, if \\( P \\) is true, then \\( R > 4 \\):\n- \\( P \\rightarrow R > 4 \\)\n\nThus, if the Hamden Plaza Subway store provides take-out service and receives many negative reviews, it cannot have a rating greater than four.         "conclusions": "The Hamden Plaza Subway store provides take-out service or does not receive many negative reviews.",
        "rationale": "<nl_cot>\nTo determine the validity of the conclusion, let's break down the premises and analyze the logical structure step-by-step.\n\n1. **Premise 1**: If a restaurant is listed in Yelp\u2019s recommendations, then the restaurant has not received many negative reviews.\n   - Symbolically: \\( L \\rightarrow \\neg N \\)\n   - Where \\( L \\) = the restaurant is listed in Yelp\u2019s recommendations, \\( N \\) = the restaurant has received many negative reviews.\n\n2. **Premise 2**: All restaurants with a rating greater than four are listed in Yelp\u2019s recommendations.\n   - Symbolically: \\( R > 4 \\rightarrow L \\)\n   - Where \\( R > 4 \\) = the restaurant has a rating greater than four.\n\n3. **Premise 3**: Some restaurants that do not provide take-out service receive many negative reviews.\n   - This does not directly relate to the Hamden Plaza Subway store but sets a condition about certain restaurants.\n\n4. **Premise 4**: All restaurants that are popular among local residents have ratings greater than four.\n   - Symbolically: \\( P \\rightarrow R > 4 \\)\n   - Where \\( P \\) = the restaurant is popular among local residents.\n\n5. **Premise 5**: The Hamden Plaza Subway store has a rating greater than four, or it is popular among local residents.\n   - Symbolically: \\( (R > 4) \\lor P \\)\n\nWe need to determine if the conclusion \"The Hamden Plaza Subway store provides take-out service or does not receive many negative reviews\" is true, false, or uncertain.\n\nLet's analyze the possible scenarios based on the premises:\n\n- **Scenario 1**: The Hamden Plaza Subway store has a rating greater than four (\\( R > 4 \\)).\n  - From Premise 2, it follows that the store is listed in Yelp\u2019s recommendations (\\( L \\)).\n  - From Premise 1, since \\( L \\) is true, \\( \\neg N \\) must be true. So, the store does not receive many negative reviews (\\( \\neg N \\)).\n\n- **Scenario 2**: The Hamden Plaza Subway store is popular among local residents (\\( P \\)).\n  - From Premise 4, if \\( P \\) is true, then \\( R > 4 \\) must be true.\n  - This leads us back to Scenario 1, where the store is listed in Yelp\u2019s recommendations and does not receive many negative reviews.\n\nIn both scenarios, the conclusion holds true because in both cases, the store either does not receive many negative reviews (Scenario 1) or the store provides take-out service (Scenario 2 is not directly addressed but can be inferred from the structure of the premises).\n\nTherefore, the conclusion is necessarily true based on the given premises.\n\n</nl_cot>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (A).\n</answer>",

Do not include any additional commentary or information outside of these tags.\n\n\nBelow are three examples that demonstrate the desired style:\n\n<EXAMPLE 1>\n<premises>\nPeter Parker is either a superhero or a civilian.\nThe Hulk is a destroyer.\nThe Hulk wakes up when he is angry.\nIf the Hulk wakes up, then he will break a bridge.\nThor is a god.\nThor will break a bridge when he is happy.\nA god is not a destroyer.\nPeter Parker wears a uniform when he is a superhero.\nPeter Parker is not a civilian if a destroyer is breaking a bridge.\nIf Thor is happy, the Hulk is angry.\n</premises>\n<conclusion>\nIf Thor is happy, then Peter Parker wears a uniform.\n</conclusion>\n<question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker wears a uniform.\n</question> \n<options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</options>\n<truth_table>\nLet:\n    T: Thor is happy\n    H: The Hulk is angry\n    A: The Hulk wakes up\n    B: A bridge is broken\n    C: Peter Parker is a civilian\n    S: Peter Parker is a superhero\n    U: Peter Parker wears a uniform\nPremises:\n    S \u2228 C\n    The Hulk is a destroyer (assumed true)\n    H \u2192 A\n    A \u2192 B\n    Thor is a god\n    T \u2192 B\n    A god is not a destroyer\n    S \u2192 U\n    B \u2192 \u00acC\n    T \u2192 H\nLogical chain (assuming T = True):\n    T = True\n    \u2192 From (10): H = True\n    H = True\n    \u2192 From (3): A = True\n    A = True\n    \u2192 From (4): B = True\n    B = True and given Hulk is a destroyer\n    \u2192 From (9): C = False\n    From (1): S \u2228 C must be true; since C is False, S = True\n    S = True\n    \u2192 From (8): U = True\nTruth Table (for T = True):\n| T (Thor is happy) | H (The Hulk is angry) | A (The Hulk wakes up) | B (A bridge is broken) | C (Peter Parker is a civilian) | S (Peter Parker is a superhero) | U (Peter Parker wears a uniform) |\n|-------------------|-----------------------|-----------------------|------------------------|---------------------------------|-----------------------------------|-----------------------------------|\n| True              | True                  | True                  | True                   | False                           | True                              | True                              |\n</truth_table>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (A).\n</answer>\n</EXAMPLE 1>\n\n<EXAMPLE 2>\n<premises>\nAll philosophers reason.\nSome sophists reason.\nAll who can reason can distinguish truth from falsehood.\nNobody who can distinguish truth from falsehood is morally perfect.\nThe theistic God is morally perfect.\nThe theistic God is a sophist.\n</premises>\n<conclusion>\nThe theistic God is a sophist and a philosopher.\n</conclusion>\n<question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? The theistic God is a sophist and a philosopher.\n</question>\n<options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</options>\n<truth_table>\nLet:\n    P: God is a philosopher\n    R: God reasons\n    D: God can distinguish truth from falsehood\n    M: God is morally perfect\n    S: God is a sophist\nPremises for God:\n    If God is a philosopher, then God reasons. (P \u2192 R)\n    (Some sophists reason; does not force God to reason.)\n    If God reasons, then God can distinguish truth from falsehood. (R \u2192 D)\n    If God can distinguish truth from falsehood, then God is not morally perfect. (D \u2192 \u00acM)\n    God is morally perfect. (M is True)\n    God is a sophist. (S is True)\nLogical chain:\n    From (5) M = True.\n    From (4), if D were True then M would be False; therefore, D must be False.\n    From (3), if R were True then D would be True; therefore, R must be False.\n    From (1), if P were True then R would be True; therefore, P must be False.\n    Given (6), S = True.\nTruth Table (for god):\n| P (Philosopher) | R (Reasons) | D (Distinguishes truth) | M (Morally Perfect) | S (Sophist) | S \u2227 P (Sophist and Philosopher) |\n|-----------------|-------------|-------------------------|---------------------|-------------|---------------------------------|\n| False           | False       | False                   | True                | True        | False                           |\n</truth_table>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (B).\n</answer>\n</EXAMPLE 2>\n\n<EXAMPLE 3>\n<premises>\nWilliam Dickinson was a British politician who sat in the House of Commons William Dickinson attended Westminster school for high school and then the University of Edinburgh. \nThe University of Edinburgh is a university located in the United Kingdom. \nWilliam Dickinson supported the Portland Whigs. \nPeople who supported the Portland Whigs did not get a seat in the Parliament.\n</premises>\n<conclusion>\nWilliam Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university.\n</conclusion>\n<question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? uncertain).\nPremises:\n    William Dickinson attended Westminster School for high school and then the University of Edinburgh.\n    The University of Edinburgh is a university located in the United Kingdom.\n    William Dickinson supported the Portland Whigs.\n    People who supported the Portland Whigs did not get a seat in the Parliament.\nConclusion to Evaluate: \n    William Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university, which translates to L \u2227 U.\nLogical Chain:\n    From (2), we know U = True.\n    However, L is not explicitly given by the premises;         "conclusions": "The Hamden Plaza store does not provide take-out service.",
        "rationale": "<nl_cot>\nLet's break down the premises and analyze them step by step to determine if the conclusion \"The Hamden Plaza store does not provide take-out service\" can be logically derived.\n\n1. **Premise 1:** If a restaurant is listed in Yelp\u2019s recommendations, then the restaurant has not received many negative reviews.\n2. **Premise 2:** All restaurants with a rating greater than four are listed in Yelp\u2019s recommendations.\n3. **Premise 3:** Some restaurants that do not provide take-out service receive many negative reviews.\n4. **Premise 4:** All restaurants that are popular among local residents have ratings greater than four.\n5. **Premise 5:** The Hamden Plaza Subway store has a rating greater than four, or it is popular among local residents.\n\nFrom these premises, let's see if we can derive the conclusion.\n\n- From Premise 2 and Premise 4, we know that restaurants with a rating greater than four (like The Hamden Plaza Subway store) are listed in Yelp\u2019s recommendations if they are popular among local residents.\n- From Premise 1, if a restaurant is listed in Yelp\u2019s recommendations, it has not received many negative reviews. \n- From Premise 3, some restaurants that do not provide take-out service receive many negative reviews. This implies that if a restaurant does not provide take-out service, it may receive many negative reviews.\n\nGiven Premise 5, The Hamden Plaza Subway store either has a rating greater than four or is popular among local residents. If it has a rating greater than four, then it is listed in Yelp\u2019s recommendations (by Premise 2). If it is listed in Yelp\u2019s recommendations, then it has not received many negative reviews (by Premise 1). \n\nSince some restaurants that do not provide take-out service receive many negative reviews (Premise 3), and The Hamden Plaza Subway store has not received many negative reviews (if it has a rating greater than four), it follows that The Hamden Plaza Subway store does not necessarily have to be one of those that do not provide take-out service.\n\nThus, the information provided does not definitively prove that The Hamden Plaza Subway store does not provide take-out service.\n</nl_cot>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (C).\n</answer>",

Therefore, since Sir Digby is a good guy, his nemesis must be a bad guy.\n\nFrom premise 4, we know that Sir Digby fights his nemesis.         "rationale": "<nl_cot>\nFrom the premises, we can analyze the logical flow as follows:\n1. Books contain tons of knowledge.\n2. When a person reads a book, that person gains knowledge.\n3. If a person gains knowledge, they become smarter.\n4. Harry read the book \"Walden\" by Henry Thoreau.\n\nWe need to determine if \"Walden\" contains knowledge. Let's break it down step by step:\n- Premise 1 tells us that books contain knowledge.\n- Premise 2 states that reading a book results in gaining knowledge.\n- Premise 4 tells us that Harry read \"Walden.\"\n- If Harry read \"Walden,\" and reading a book results in gaining knowledge (from premise 2), then Harry gained knowledge from reading \"Walden.\"\n- Premise 3 indicates that gaining knowledge makes a person smarter, but this does not directly relate to the content of the book.\n\nThe key here is to understand that the act of gaining knowledge from reading a book (premise 2) implies that the book contains the knowledge that was gained. Therefore, since Harry read \"Walden\" and gained knowledge from it, it logically follows that \"Walden\" must contain knowledge.\n\nThere is no information provided that contradicts this conclusion. Thus, based on the given premises, we can logically infer that \"Walden\" contains knowledge.\n</nl_cot>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (A).\n</answer>",

        "rationale": "<nl_cot>\nWe need to analyze the premises to determine if the conclusion logically follows. Let's break down the premises:\n\n1. A natural language processing task can be categorized as either a language generation task or a language understanding task.\n2. If the output of a natural language processing task is a text sequence, then it is a language generation task.\n3. Machine translation is a natural language processing task.\n4. The output of machine translation is a text sequence.\n\nFrom premise 4, we know that machine translation produces a text sequence. According to premise 2, if the output of a natural language processing task is a text sequence, then it is a language generation task. Since machine translation is a natural language processing task and its output is a text sequence, it follows that machine translation is a language generation task.\n\nThe conclusion directly follows from the premises provided.\n</nl_cot>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (A).\n</answer>",

The theistic God is a sophist and a philosopher.\n</question>\n<options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</options>\n<truth_table>\nLet:\n    P: God is a philosopher\n    R: God reasons\n    D: God can distinguish truth from falsehood\n    M: God is morally perfect\n    S: God is a sophist\nPremises for God:\n    If God is a philosopher, then God reasons. A natural language processing task can be categorized as either a language generation task or a language understanding task.\n2. If the output of a natural language processing task is a text sequence, then it is a language generation task.\n3. Machine translation is a natural language processing task.\n4. The output of machine translation is a text sequence.\n\nFrom premise 4, we know that machine translation produces a text sequence. According to premise 2, if the output is a text sequence, then it is a language generation task. Therefore, machine translation is a language generation task, not a language understanding task.\n\nThe conclusion states that machine translation is a language understanding task, which directly contradicts the logical deduction from the premises.\n</nl_cot>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (B).\n</answer>",

        "conclusions": "Tom is allowed to move into an apartment in The Olive Garden with Fluffy.",
        "rationale": "<nl_cot>\nTo determine if Tom is allowed to move into an apartment in The Olive Garden with Fluffy, we need to follow the given premises step by step.\n\n1. **Pets are allowed in some managed buildings.**\n   - This implies that at least one managed building allows pets. However, it does not specify which managed buildings allow pets. \n\n2. **A deposit is required to rent an apartment in a managed building.**\n   - This is a general requirement for renting in managed buildings.\n\n3. **The security deposit can be either equal to the monthly rent at a managed building or more.**\n   - This means the deposit can be at least $2000 (the monthly rent at the Olive Garden) or more.\n\n4. **Fluffy is Tom's cat.**\n   - Fluffy is a specific pet.\n\n5. **Cats are pets.**\n   - Cats fall under the category of pets.\n\n6. **The Olive Garden is a managed building.**\n   - The Olive Garden is one of the managed buildings.\n\n7. **The monthly rent at the Olive Garden is $2000.**\n   - This is the specific monthly rent for the Olive Garden.\n\n8. **$2000 is more than $1500.**\n   - This is a numerical comparison.\n\n9. **Tom will rent an apartment in a managed building if he is allowed to move in with Fluffy, and the security deposit is no more than $1500.**\n   - This condition specifies that Tom can rent if he can bring a pet and the deposit is capped at $1500.\n\n10. **If a managed building allows pets, then people are allowed to move in with a pet.**\n    - This is a direct implication that if pets are allowed in a managed building, people can bring them.\n\nGiven these premises:\n- We know that Fluffy is a cat, and cats are pets.\n- The Olive Garden is a managed building.\n- Pets are allowed in some managed buildings, and The Olive Garden is one of them.\n- The monthly rent at the Olive Garden is $2000, and the security deposit can be $2000 or more.\n- Tom can only rent if the deposit is no more than $1500.\n\nSince the security deposit at the Olive Garden is $2000, which is more than $1500, Tom cannot meet the condition for renting based on the deposit requirement. \n\nTherefore, even though pets are allowed in the Olive Garden, the security deposit requirement prevents Tom from renting an apartment with Fluffy.\n</nl_cot>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (B).\n</answer>",

        "rationale": "<nl_cot>\nLet's break down the premises and the conclusion step by step.\n\n1. All business organizations are legal entities.\n2. All companies are business organizations.\n3. All private companies are companies.\n4. All legal entities are created under law.\n5. All legal entities have legal obligations.\n6. If the Harvard Weekly Book Club is created under law, then it is not a private company.\n\nFrom these, we need to derive the conclusion:\n- If the Harvard Weekly Book Club is a private company, then it either has legal obligations or is created under law.\n\nFirst, let's analyze the premises related to the Harvard Weekly Book Club:\n\n- Since all companies are business organizations (Premise 2), and all business organizations are legal entities (Premise 1), the Harvard Weekly Book Club, if it is a company, must be a legal entity.\n- All legal entities are created under law (Premise 4), so if the Harvard Weekly Book Club is a legal entity, it is created under law.\n- All legal entities have legal obligations (Premise 5), so if the Harvard Weekly Book Club is a legal entity, it has legal obligations.\n- If the Harvard Weekly Book Club is created under law, then it is not a private company (Premise 6).\n\nNow, let's consider the statement we need to evaluate:\n- If the Harvard Weekly Book Club is a private company, then it either has legal obligations or is created under law.\n\nSince all private companies are companies (Premise 3), and all companies are business organizations (Premise 2), the Harvard Weekly Book Club, if it is a private company, must be a business organization and a legal entity.\n\nFrom Premise 4, all legal entities are created under law. Therefore, if the Harvard Weekly Book Club is a private company, it must be a legal entity and, consequently, created under law.\n\nSince the Harvard Weekly Book Club, if a private company, is created under law, it cannot have legal obligations (as it would contradict Premise 6). Therefore, the only way for the statement to hold true is if the Harvard Weekly Book Club is created under law.\n\nThus, if the Harvard Weekly Book Club is a private company, it must be created under law, which means it either has legal obligations (which it does not, but the condition is met by being created under law).\n\nHence, the statement is true.\n</nl_cot>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (A).\n</answer>",

        "premises": "Animals are either invertebrates or vertebrates.\nAll animals with backbones reproduce by male-and-female mating. \nAll vertebrate animals have a backbone.\nAll bees do not reproduce by male-and-female mating.\nAll queen bees are bees.\nHarry is a bee.",
        "conclusions": "Harry is a queen bee.",
        "rationale": "Let:\n- A: Harry is an animal.\n- B: Harry is a bee.\n- C: Harry is a queen bee.\n- D: Harry reproduces by male-and-female mating.\n- E: Harry has a backbone.\n- F: Harry is an invertebrate.\n- G: Harry is a vertebrate.\n\nPremises:\n1. Animals are either invertebrates or vertebrates. (A \u2192 F \u2228 G)\n2. All animals with backbones reproduce by male-and-female mating. (E \u2192 D)\n3. All vertebrate animals have a backbone. (G \u2192 E)\n4. All bees do not reproduce by male-and-female mating. (B \u2192 \u00acD)\n5. All queen bees are bees. (C \u2192 B)\n6. Harry is a bee. (B)\n\nLogical Chain:\n1. From premise 6, B = True.\n2. From premise 4, B \u2192 \u00acD, and since B = True, \u00acD must be True. Therefore, D = False.\n3. From premise 2, E \u2192 D, and since D = False, E must be False (if E were True, D would have to be True, but it is False).\n4. From premise 3, G \u2192 E, and since E = False, G must be False (if G were True, E would have to be True, but it is False).\n5. From premise 1, A \u2192 F \u2228 G. Since G = False, A must be False or F must be True.\n6. From premise 5, C \u2192 B, and since B = True, C must be True (if C were False, B would have to be False, but B is True).\n7. Since C = True, Harry is a queen bee.\n\nTruth Table:\n| A (Harry is an animal) | B (Harry is a bee) | C (Harry is a queen bee) | D (Harry reproduces by male-and-female mating) | E (Harry has a backbone) | F (Harry is an invertebrate) | G (Harry is a vertebrate) |\n|------------------------|--------------------|--------------------------|------------------------------------------------|--------------------------|------------------------------|--------------------------|\n| False                  | True               | True                     | False                                         | False                    | True                         | False                    |\n\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (A).\n</answer>",

        "premises": "Animals are either invertebrates or vertebrates.\nAll animals with backbones reproduce by male-and-female mating. \nAll vertebrate animals have a backbone.\nAll bees do not reproduce by male-and-female mating.\nAll queen bees are bees.\nHarry is a bee.",
        "conclusions": "If Harry is either both a vertebrate and an animal with a backbone, or neither a vertebrate nor an animal with a backbone, then Harry is neither an invertebrate nor a queen bee.",
        "rationale": "<nl_cot>\nLet's analyze the given premises and the conclusion step-by-step:\n\n1. **Premise Analysis:**\n   - Animals are either invertebrates or vertebrates.\n   - All animals with backbones reproduce by male-and-female mating.\n   - All vertebrate animals have a backbone.\n   - All bees do not reproduce by male-and-female mating.\n   - All queen bees are bees.\n   - Harry is a bee.\n\n2. **Implications from the Premises:**\n   - Since all bees do not reproduce by male-and-female mating, and all animals with backbones do, bees do not have backbones. Therefore, bees are invertebrates.\n   - Since all queen bees are bees, and bees are invertebrates, queen bees are invertebrates.\n   - Since all vertebrate animals have a backbone, and bees do not have a backbone, bees cannot be vertebrates.\n\n3. **Harry's Classification:**\n   - Since Harry is a bee, Harry is an invertebrate and does not have a backbone.\n   - Therefore, Harry cannot be a vertebrate and cannot have a backbone.\n\n4. **Conclusion Analysis:**\n   - The conclusion states: \"If Harry is either both a vertebrate and an animal with a backbone, or neither a vertebrate nor an animal with a backbone, then Harry is neither an invertebrate nor a queen bee.\"\n   - From the premises, we know that Harry is an invertebrate and does not have a backbone, so he cannot be both a vertebrate and an animal with a backbone.\n   - Also, since Harry is a bee, he is a queen bee (since all bees are queen bees).\n\n5. **Verification of the Conclusion:**\n   - If Harry is neither a vertebrate nor an animal with a backbone, he fits the \"neither a vertebrate nor an animal with a backbone\" part of the condition.\n   - Given that Harry is an invertebrate, the conclusion states he is \"neither an invertebrate nor a queen bee,\" which contradicts the fact that Harry is a queen bee (and hence an invertebrate).\n\nTherefore, the statement is false because the conclusion contradicts the known facts about Harry being an invertebrate and a queen bee.\n</nl_cot>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (B).\n</answer>",

        "premises": "People who are born in a multiple birth with siblings spend a lot of time hanging out with and playing with their siblings.\nIf people have siblings who were born together, then they were born in a multiple birth.\nIf people complain often about annoying siblings, then they have siblings who were born together.\nIf people live at home, then they do not live with strangers.\nIf people spend a lot of time hanging out with and playing with their siblings, then they often live at home. \nLuke either is a baby born in a multiple birth and live with strangers, or is not a baby born in a multiple birth and does not live with strangers",
        "conclusions": "Luke spends a lot of time hanging out and playing with his siblings.",
        "rationale": "<nl_cot>\nWe need to analyze the premises step by step to determine if the conclusion that Luke spends a lot of time hanging out and playing with his siblings is true, false, or uncertain.\n\n1. **Premise 1**: People who are born in a multiple birth with siblings spend a lot of time hanging out with and playing with their siblings.\n2. **Premise 2**: If people have siblings who were born together, then they were born in a multiple birth.\n3. **Premise 3**: If people complain often about annoying siblings, then they have siblings who were born together.\n4. **Premise 4**: If people live at home, then they do not live with strangers.\n5. **Premise 5**: If people spend a lot of time hanging out with and playing with their siblings, then they often live at home.\n\n**Premise 6**: Luke either is a baby born in a multiple birth and lives with strangers, or is not a baby born in a multiple birth and does not live with strangers.\n\nLet's break this down:\n\n- From Premise 6, we know that Luke's situation must fit one of the two cases:\n  1. Luke is born in a multiple birth and lives with strangers.\n  2. Luke is not born in a multiple birth and does not live with strangers.\n\n**Case 1**: Luke is born in a multiple birth and lives with strangers.\n- From Premise 1, people born in a multiple birth spend a lot of time with their siblings.\n- From Premise 4, if Luke lives at home, he does not live with strangers. However, this case does not specify where Luke lives, only that he lives with strangers. Thus, we cannot directly use Premise 4 in this case.\n\n**Case 2**: Luke is not born in a multiple birth and does not live with strangers.\n- From Premise 5, if Luke spends a lot of time with his siblings, he often lives at home. But in this case, Luke does not live with strangers, and we need to determine if he lives at home.\n- Premise 4 states that if people live at home, they do not live with strangers. Since Luke does not live with strangers, he must live at home.\n- From Premise 5, if Luke lives at home, he often spends a lot of time with his siblings.\n\nSince in Case 2, Luke does not live with strangers and lives at home, he must spend a lot of time with his siblings.\n\nSince we have shown that in at least one of the possible cases (Case 2), Luke spends a lot of time with his siblings, the conclusion that Luke spends a lot of time hanging out and playing with his siblings is true.\n\n</nl_cot>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (A).\n</answer>",

The theistic God is a sophist and a philosopher.\n</question>\n<options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</options>\n<truth_table>\nLet:\n    P: God is a philosopher\n    R: God reasons\n    D: God can distinguish truth from falsehood\n    M: God is morally perfect\n    S: God is a sophist\nPremises for God:\n    If God is a philosopher, then God reasons. (P \u2192 R)\n    (Some sophists reason; does not force God to reason.)\n    If God reasons, then God can distinguish truth from falsehood. (R \u2192 D)\n    If God can distinguish truth from falsehood, then God is not morally perfect. (D \u2192 \u00acM)\n    God is morally perfect. (M is True)\n    God is a sophist. (S is True)\nLogical chain:\n    From (5) M = True.\n    From (4), if D were True then M would be False; therefore, D must be False.\n    From (3), if R were True then D would be True; therefore, R must be False.\n    From (1), if P were True then R would be True; therefore, P must be False.\n    Given (6), S = True.\nTruth Table (for god):\n| P (Philosopher) | R (Reasons) | D (Distinguishes truth) | M (Morally Perfect) | S (Sophist) | S \u2227 P (Sophist and Philosopher) |\n|-----------------|-------------|-------------------------|---------------------|-------------|---------------------------------|\n| False           | False       | False                   | True                | True        | False                           |\n</truth_table>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (B).\n</answer>\n</EXAMPLE 2>\n\n<EXAMPLE 3>\n<premises>\nWilliam Dickinson was a British politician who sat in the House of Commons William Dickinson attended Westminster school for high school and then the University of Edinburgh. \nThe University of Edinburgh is a university located in the United Kingdom. \nWilliam Dickinson supported the Portland Whigs. \nPeople who supported the Portland Whigs did not get a seat in the Parliament.\n</premises>\n<conclusion>\nWilliam Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university.\n</conclusion>\n<question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain?         "rationale": "Let's analyze the premises and the conclusion step by step.\n\n<nl_cot>\n1. People who are born in a multiple birth with siblings spend a lot of time hanging out with and playing with their siblings.\n2. If people have siblings who were born together, then they were born in a multiple birth.\n3. If people complain often about annoying siblings, then they have siblings who were born together.\n4. If people live at home, then they do not live with strangers.\n5. If people spend a lot of time hanging out with and playing with their siblings, then they often live at home.\n6. Luke either is a baby born in a multiple birth and live with strangers, or is not a baby born in a multiple birth and does not live with strangers.\n</nl_cot>\n\nNow, let's break down the logical structure of the problem.\n\n<nl_cot>\n- From premise 6, we have two cases to consider:\n  - Case 1: Luke is a baby born in a multiple birth and lives with strangers.\n  - Case 2: Luke is not a baby born in a multiple birth and does not live with strangers.\n  \nLet's analyze each case separately.\n\nCase 1:\n- If Luke is a baby born in a multiple birth and lives with strangers, then:\n  - From premise 1, he would spend a lot of time hanging out with and playing with his siblings.\n  - From premise 5, if he spends a lot of time hanging out with and playing with his siblings, then he often lives at home.\n  - However, premise 4 states that if people live at home, then they do not live with strangers. This creates a contradiction because he cannot both live at home and live with strangers simultaneously.\n  - Therefore, Case 1 is not possible.\n\nCase 2:\n- If Luke is not a baby born in a multiple birth and does not live with strangers, then:\n  - He does not have the conditions that would lead to spending a lot of time with his siblings.\n  - From premise 3, if people complain often about annoying siblings, then they have siblings who were born together. Since Luke is not a baby born in a multiple birth, he does not have siblings who were born together, and therefore, he cannot complain often about annoying siblings.\n</nl_cot>\n\nSince both cases lead to contradictions or logical impossibilities, the only consistent scenario is that Luke does not complain often about annoying siblings.\n\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (B).\n</answer>",
