(P \u2192 R)\n    (Some sophists reason; does not force God to reason.)\n    If God reasons, then God can distinguish truth from falsehood. (R \u2192 D)\n    If God can distinguish truth from falsehood, then God is not morally perfect. (D \u2192 \u00acM)\n    God is morally perfect. (M is True)\n    God is a sophist. (S is True)\nLogical chain:\n    From (5) M = True.\n    From (4), if D were True then M would be False; therefore, D must be False.\n    From (3), if R were True then D would be True; therefore, R must be False.\n    From (1), if P were True then R would be True; therefore, P must be False.\n    Given (6), S = True.\nTruth Table (for god):\n| P (Philosopher) | R (Reasons) | D (Distinguishes truth) | M (Morally Perfect) | S (Sophist) | S \u2227 P (Sophist and Philosopher) |\n|-----------------|-------------|-------------------------|---------------------|-------------|---------------------------------|\n| False           | False       | False                   | True                | True        | False                           |\n</truth_table>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (B).\n</answer>\n</EXAMPLE 2>\n\n<EXAMPLE 3>\n<premises>\nWilliam Dickinson was a British politician who sat in the House of Commons William Dickinson attended Westminster school for high school and then the University of Edinburgh. \nThe University of Edinburgh is a university located in the United Kingdom. \nWilliam Dickinson supported the Portland Whigs. \nPeople who supported the Portland Whigs did not get a seat in the Parliament.\n</premises>\n<conclusion>\nWilliam Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university.\n</conclusion>\n<question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? William Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university.\n</question> \n<options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</options>\n<truth_table>\nLet:\n    W: William Dickinson attended Westminster School for high school.\n    E: William Dickinson attended the University of Edinburgh.\n    U: The University of Edinburgh is located in the United Kingdom (Given explicitly, so U = True).\n    L: Westminster School is located in the United Kingdom (Not explicitly stated; uncertain).\nPremises:\n    William Dickinson attended Westminster School for high school and then the University of Edinburgh.\n    The University of Edinburgh is a university located in the United Kingdom.\n    William Dickinson supported the Portland Whigs.\n    People who supported the Portland Whigs did not get a seat in the Parliament.\nConclusion to Evaluate: \n    William Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university, which translates to L \u2227 U.\nLogical Chain:\n    From (2), we know U = True.\n    However, L is not explicitly given by the premises; although implied by context, it remains uncertain.\n    Therefore, since U = True but L is uncertain, the conjunction L \u2227 U is uncertain.\nTruth Table (Key Possibilities):\n| L (Westminster School in UK) | U (University of Edinburgh in UK) | L \u2227 U (Both in UK) |\n|------------------------------|------------------------------------|--------------------|\n| True                         | True                               | True               |\n| False                        | True                               | False              |\n</truth_table>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (C).\n</answer>\n</EXAMPLE 3>\n\n\nThe following is the problem you need to solve.\n\n<premises>\nNone of the students who currently work in the library are from the computer science department. \nAll of the students with part-time jobs offered by the university currently work in the library. \nAll of the students who are taking the database course are from the computer science department. \nAll of the students taking a class with Professor David are taking the database course. \nAll students working in the lab are taking a class with Professor David.\nJames is a student working in the lab. \nJames doesn't work in the lab or have a part-time job offered by the university.\n</premises>\n<conclusion>\nJames has a part-time job offered by the university.\n</conclusion>\n<question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? James has a part-time job offered by the university.\n</question>\n<options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</options>\n<truth_table>\n"

According to Premise 5, all students working in the lab are taking a class with Professor David. Therefore, James is taking a class with Professor David.\n\nFrom Premise 4, since James is taking a class with Professor David, he must be taking the database course. From Premise 3, all students taking the database course are from the computer science department. Therefore, James is from the computer science department.\n\nFrom Premise 2, all students with part-time jobs offered by the university currently work in the library. Premise 1 states that none of the students who currently work in the library are from the computer science department. Since James is from the computer science department, he cannot be one of the students with part-time jobs offered by the university.\n\nFinally, Premise 7 explicitly states that James doesn't have a part-time job offered by the university.\n\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (A).\n</answer>",

All of the students with part-time jobs offered by the university currently work in the library.\n3. James doesn't work in the lab or have a part-time job offered by the university.\n\nFrom the premises, we can derive the following logical implications:\n- Since James is working in the lab (L), from premise 5, James is taking a class with Professor David (DB).\n- From premise 4, since James is taking a class with Professor David, he is taking the database course (D).\n- From premise 3, since James is taking the database course, he is from the computer science department (C).\n- From premise 1, since James is from the computer science department, he does not work in the library.\n- From premise 2, since James does not work in the library, he does not have a part-time job offered by the university (P).\n\nGiven the premises, James is taking the database course (D) and does not have a part-time job offered by the university (P). The theistic God is a sophist and a philosopher.\n</question>\n<options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</options>\n<truth_table>\nLet:\n    P: God is a philosopher\n    R: God reasons\n    D: God can distinguish truth from falsehood\n    M: God is morally perfect\n    S: God is a sophist\nPremises for God:\n    If God is a philosopher, then God reasons. (P \u2192 R)\n    (Some sophists reason; does not force God to reason.)\n    If God reasons, then God can distinguish truth from falsehood. (R \u2192 D)\n    If God can distinguish truth from falsehood, then God is not morally perfect. (D \u2192 \u00acM)\n    God is morally perfect. (M is True)\n    God is a sophist. (S is True)\nLogical chain:\n    From (5) M = True.\n    From (4), if D were True then M would be False; therefore, D must be False.\n    From (3), if R were True then D would be True; therefore, R must be False.\n    From (1), if P were True then R would be True; therefore, P must be False.\n    Given (6), S = True.\nTruth Table (for god):\n| P (Philosopher) | R (Reasons) | D (Distinguishes truth) | M (Morally Perfect) | S (Sophist) | S \u2227 P (Sophist and Philosopher) |\n|-----------------|-------------|-------------------------|---------------------|-------------|---------------------------------|\n| False           | False       | False                   | True                | True        | False                           |\n</truth_table>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (B).\n</answer>\n</EXAMPLE 2>\n\n<EXAMPLE 3>\n<premises>\nWilliam Dickinson was a British politician who sat in the House of Commons William Dickinson attended Westminster school for high school and then the University of Edinburgh. \nThe University of Edinburgh is a university located in the United Kingdom. \nWilliam Dickinson supported the Portland Whigs. \nPeople who supported the Portland Whigs did not get a seat in the Parliament.\n</premises>\n<conclusion>\nWilliam Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university.\n</conclusion>\n<question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? \u2192 W  (If George likes music, he wants to compose.)\n    P \u2192 C  (If George has access to a program, he can compose.)\n    (C \u2227 W) \u2192 A  (If George can compose and wants to compose, \u00acC \u2228 \u00acW\n    This means if George will not compose, either George can not compose or George does not want to compose.\n    However, the conclusion only states that George can not         "rationale": "Let:\n    H: A hawk never swims.\n    B: Some birds are hawks.\n    S: All birds swim.\n\nPremises:\n    H: A hawk never swims.\n    B: Some birds are hawks.\n\nConclusion to Evaluate:\n    S: All birds swim.\n\nLogical Chain:\n    From premise H, we know that hawks do not swim.\n    From premise B, we know that there are some birds that are hawks.\n    Combining these, we can deduce that at least one bird (the hawk) does not swim.\n    Therefore, it is not possible for all birds to swim, because there exists at least one bird (the hawk) that does not swim.\n\nTruth Table (Key Possibilities):\n| S (All birds swim) |\n|--------------------|\n| False              |\n\nSince we have shown that at least one bird (the hawk) does not swim, the statement \"All birds swim\" must be false.\n\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (B).\n</answer>",

The theistic God is a sophist and a philosopher.\n</question>\n<options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</options>\n<truth_table>\nLet:\n    P: God is a philosopher\n    R: God reasons\n    D: God can distinguish truth from falsehood\n    M: God is morally perfect\n    S: God is a sophist\nPremises for God:\n    If God is a philosopher, then God reasons. (P \u2192 R)\n    (Some sophists reason; does not force God to reason.)\n    If God reasons, then God can distinguish truth from falsehood. (R \u2192 D)\n    If God can distinguish truth from falsehood, then God is not morally perfect. (D \u2192 \u00acM)\n    God is morally perfect. (M is True)\n    God is a sophist. (S is True)\nLogical chain:\n    From (5) M = True.\n    From (4), if D were True then M would be False; therefore, D must be False.\n    From (3), if R were True then D would be True; therefore, R must be False.\n    From (1), if P were True then R would be True; therefore, P must be False.\n    Given (6), S = True.\nTruth Table (for god):\n| P (Philosopher) | R (Reasons) | D (Distinguishes truth) | M (Morally Perfect) | S (Sophist) | S \u2227 P (Sophist and Philosopher) |\n|-----------------|-------------|-------------------------|---------------------|-------------|---------------------------------|\n| False           | False       | False                   | True                | True        | False                           |\n</truth_table>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (B).\n</answer>\n</EXAMPLE 2>\n\n<EXAMPLE 3>\n<premises>\nWilliam Dickinson was a British politician who sat in the House of Commons William Dickinson attended Westminster school for high school and then the University of Edinburgh. \nThe University of Edinburgh is a university located in the United Kingdom. \nWilliam Dickinson supported the Portland Whigs. \nPeople who supported the Portland Whigs did not get a seat in the Parliament.\n</premises>\n<conclusion>\nWilliam Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university.\n</conclusion>\n<question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? William Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university.\n</question> \n<options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</options>\n<truth_table>\nLet:\n    W: William Dickinson attended Westminster School for high school.\n    E: William Dickinson attended the University of Edinburgh.\n    U: The University of Edinburgh is located in the United Kingdom (Given explicitly, so U = True).\n    L: Westminster School is located in the United Kingdom (Not explicitly stated; uncertain).\nPremises:\n    William Dickinson attended Westminster School for high school and then the University of Edinburgh.\n    The University of Edinburgh is a university located in the United Kingdom.\n    William Dickinson supported the Portland Whigs.\n    People who supported the Portland Whigs did not get a seat in the Parliament.\nConclusion to Evaluate: \n    William Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university, which translates to L \u2227 U.\nLogical Chain:\n    From (2), we know U = True.\n    However, L is not explicitly given by the premises; although implied by context, it remains uncertain.\n    Therefore, since U = True but L is uncertain, the conjunction L \u2227 U is uncertain.\nTruth Table (Key Possibilities):\n| L (Westminster School in UK) | U (University of Edinburgh in UK) | L \u2227 U (Both in UK) |\n|------------------------------|------------------------------------|--------------------|\n| True                         | True                               | True               |\n| False                        | True                               | False              |\n</truth_table>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (C).\n</answer>\n</EXAMPLE 3>\n\n\nThe following is the problem you need to solve.\n\n<premises>\nA hawk never swims. \nSome birds are hawks.\n</premises>\n<conclusion>\nAll birds swim.\n</conclusion>\n<question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? Some show airing at 8 pm on Monday gives out roses on TV.\n2. If a show gives out roses on TV, then the show is an episode of The Bachelor.\n3. The Bachelor portrays the lives of real people.\n4. All shows portraying the lives of real people are reality TV shows.\n5. Breaking Bad is a show.\n6. Breaking Bad is not a reality TV show.\n\nFrom premise 1, we know there exists at least one show that gives out roses on TV and airs at 8 pm on Monday. Let's denote this show as X. So, X gives out roses on TV and X airs at 8 pm on Monday.\n\nFrom premise 2, if a show gives out roses on TV, then it is an episode of The Bachelor. Therefore, X is an episode of The Bachelor.\n\nFrom premise 3, The Bachelor portrays the lives of real people.\n\nFrom premise 4, all shows portraying the lives of real people are reality TV shows. Therefore, The Bachelor, which portrays the lives of real people, is a reality TV show.\n\nHowever, premise 6 states that Breaking Bad is not a reality TV show. Since X is an episode of The Bachelor and The Bachelor is a reality TV show, X cannot be Breaking Bad. Therefore, X is not Breaking Bad.\n\nSince X is not Breaking Bad and X is the show that gives out roses on TV and airs at 8 pm on Monday, it follows that Breaking Bad does not give out roses on TV and does not air at 8 pm on Monday.\n\nThus, we can conclude that the statement \"Breaking Bad is on Monday at 8 pm\" is false.\n\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (B).\n</answer>",

        "premises": "Some show airing at 8 pm on Monday gives out roses on TV.\nIf a show gives out roses on TV, then the show is an episode of The Bachelor.\nThe Bachelor portrays the lives of real people.\nAll shows portraying the lives of real people are reality TV shows.\nBreaking Bad is a show.\nBreaking Bad is not a reality TV show.",
        "conclusions": "Breaking Bad is a TV show in which roses are given out on Monday at 8 pm.",
        "rationale": "Let:\n- R: A show gives out roses on TV.\n- B8M: A show airs at 8 pm on Monday.\n- T: The show is an episode of The Bachelor.\n- P: The show portrays the lives of real people.\n- RT: The show is a reality TV show.\n- BB: Breaking Bad.\nPremises:\n1. Some show airing at 8 pm on Monday gives out roses on TV.\n2. If a show gives out roses on TV, then the show is an episode of The Bachelor.\n3. The Bachelor portrays the lives of real people.\n4. All shows portraying the lives of real people are reality TV shows.\n5. Breaking Bad is a show.\n6. Breaking Bad is not a reality TV show.\nLogical Chain:\n- From (1): \u2203x (B8M(x) \u2227 R(x)) (There exists a show that airs at 8 pm on Monday and gives out roses on TV).\n- From (2): R(x) \u2192 T(x) (If a show gives out roses on TV, then it is an episode of The Bachelor).\n- From (3): T(x) \u2192 P(x) (If a show is an episode of The Bachelor, then it portrays the lives of real people).\n- From (4): P(x) \u2192 RT(x) (If a show portrays the lives of real people, then it is a reality TV show).\n- From (5) and (6): BB is a show, and BB is not a reality TV show (BB \u2209 RT).\nLogical chain for BB:\n- Assume BB gives out roses on TV (R(BB)).\n- From (2), if R(BB), then BB is an episode of The Bachelor (T(BB)).\n- From (3), if T(BB), then BB portrays the lives of real people (P(BB)).\n- From (4), if P(BB), then BB is a reality TV show (BB \u2208 RT).\n- However, from (6), BB is not a reality TV show (BB \u2209 RT).\n- Therefore, the assumption that BB gives out roses on TV leads to a contradiction.\nTruth Table (for BB giving out roses on TV):\n| R(BB) (Roses given out) | BB is an episode of The Bachelor (T(BB)) | BB portrays the lives of real people (P(BB)) | BB is a reality TV show (BB \u2208 RT) | BB \u2209 RT (Contradiction) |\n|-------------------------|------------------------------------------|---------------------------------------------|----------------------------------|-------------------------|\n| True                    | True                                     | True                                        | True                             | False                   |\n\nSince the assumption that BB gives out roses on TV leads to a contradiction, the statement is false.\n\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (B).\n</answer>",

        "premises": "Some show airing at 8 pm on Monday gives out roses on TV.\nIf a show gives out roses on TV, then the show is an episode of The Bachelor.\nThe Bachelor portrays the lives of real people.\nAll shows portraying the lives of real people are reality TV shows.\nBreaking Bad is a show.\nBreaking Bad is not a reality TV show.",
        "conclusions": "If roses are given out during Breaking Bad, then it is on Monday at 8 pm.",
        "rationale": "<nl_cot>\nLet's analyze the given premises step by step to determine if the conclusion logically follows.\n\n1. Some show airing at 8 pm on Monday gives out roses on TV.\n2. If a show gives out roses on TV, then the show is an episode of The Bachelor.\n3. The Bachelor portrays the lives of real people.\n4. All shows portraying the lives of real people are reality TV shows.\n5. Breaking Bad is a show.\n6. Breaking Bad is not a reality TV show.\n\nFrom premise 5 and 6, we know that Breaking Bad is not a reality TV show. However, premise 4 states that all shows portraying the lives of real people are reality TV shows. This implies that for a show to portray the lives of real people, it must be a reality TV show. Therefore, if a show is not a reality TV show, it cannot portray the lives of real people.\n\nPremise 3 states that The Bachelor portrays the lives of real people, so The Bachelor must be a reality TV show according to premise 4.\n\nPremise 2 states that if a show gives out roses on TV, then it is an episode of The Bachelor. This means that for a show to give out roses, it must be an episode of The Bachelor.\n\nPremise 1 states that some show airing at 8 pm on Monday gives out roses on TV. This means there exists at least one show that gives out roses at 8 pm on Monday, and by premise 2, this show must be an episode of The Bachelor.\n\nCombining these, if roses are given out during a show, that show must be an episode of The Bachelor. However, the conclusion states that if roses are given out during Breaking Bad, then it is on Monday at 8 pm. This is not necessarily true because Breaking Bad is not an episode of The Bachelor (as it is not a reality TV show), and therefore, it cannot be the show that gives out roses at 8 pm on Monday.\n\nThus, the statement \"If roses are given out during Breaking Bad, then it is on Monday at 8 pm\" is false.\n</nl_cot>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (B).\n</answer>",

        "premises": "If something is a deadly disease, then it comes with a low survival rate. \nSevere cancers are deadly diseases.\nBile duct cancer is a severe form cancer. \nAll Cholangiocarcinoma is bile duct cancer.\nMild flu comes with a low survival rate.\nColorectal cancer is not both a bile duct cancer and with a low survival rate.",
        "conclusions": "If colorectal cancer is a kind of bile duct cancer or a form of Cholangiocarcinoma, then colorectal cancer is a kind of bile duct cancer and a kind of mild flu.",
        "rationale": "<nl_cot>\nLet's analyze the given premises step by step to determine the validity of the conclusion.\n\n1. **Premise 1:** If something is a deadly disease, then it comes with a low survival rate.\n2. **Premise 2:** Severe cancers are deadly diseases.\n3. **Premise 3:** Bile duct cancer is a severe form of cancer.\n4. **Premise 4:** All Cholangiocarcinoma is bile duct cancer.\n5. **Premise 5:** Mild flu comes with a low survival rate.\n6. **Premise 6:** Colorectal cancer is not both a bile duct cancer and with a low survival rate.\n\nFrom these premises, we need to evaluate the statement:\n\"If colorectal cancer is a kind of bile duct cancer or a form of Cholangiocarcinoma, then colorectal cancer is a kind of bile duct cancer and a kind of mild flu.\"\n\nLet's break it down:\n\n- From Premise 3 and Premise 2, we know that bile duct cancer is a severe cancer, and severe cancers are deadly diseases. Therefore, bile duct cancer comes with a low survival rate.\n- From Premise 4, Cholangiocarcinoma is a type of bile duct cancer.\n- From Premise 6, colorectal cancer is not both a bile duct cancer and with a low survival rate. This means if colorectal cancer is a bile duct cancer, it must not have a low survival rate, which contradicts Premise 5 that mild flu (which is a low survival rate disease) is a mild flu.\n- If colorectal cancer is a form of Cholangiocarcinoma, then it is a bile duct cancer (Premise 4), and we already established that bile duct cancer has a low survival rate (Premise 5).\n\nNow, let's analyze the statement:\n- If colorectal cancer is a kind of bile duct cancer or a form of Cholangiocarcinoma, then it is a bile duct cancer (since Cholangiocarcinoma is a type of bile duct cancer).\n- However, the statement also claims that colorectal cancer is a mild flu, which contradicts Premise 5, as mild flu is a low survival rate disease, and colorectal cancer cannot be a mild flu if it is a bile duct cancer (which has a low survival rate).\n\nSince the statement requires colorectal cancer to be both a bile duct cancer and a mild flu, which is impossible based on the given premises, the statement is false.\n</nl_cot>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (B).\n</answer>",

(S is True)\nLogical chain:\n    From (5) M = True.\n    From (4), if D were True then M would be False; therefore, D must be False.\n    From (3), if R were True then D would be True; therefore, R must be False.\n    From (1), if P were True then R would be True; therefore, P must be False.\n    Given (6), S = True.\nTruth Table (for god):\n| P (Philosopher) | R (Reasons) | D (Distinguishes truth) | M (Morally Perfect) | S (Sophist) | S \u2227 P (Sophist and Philosopher) |\n|-----------------|-------------|-------------------------|---------------------|-------------|---------------------------------|\n| False           | False       | False                   | True                | True        | False                           |\n</truth_table>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (B).\n</answer>\n</EXAMPLE 2>\n\n<EXAMPLE 3>\n<premises>\nWilliam Dickinson was a British politician who sat in the House of Commons William Dickinson attended Westminster school for high school and then the University of Edinburgh. \nThe University of Edinburgh is a university located in the United Kingdom. \nWilliam Dickinson supported the Portland Whigs. \nPeople who supported the Portland Whigs did not get a seat in the Parliament.\n</premises>\n<conclusion>\nWilliam Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university.\n</conclusion>\n<question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? William Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university.\n</question> \n<options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</options>\n<truth_table>\nLet:\n    W: William Dickinson attended Westminster School for high school.\n    E: William Dickinson attended the University of Edinburgh.\n    U: The University of Edinburgh is located in the United Kingdom (Given explicitly, so U = True).\n    L: Westminster School is located in the United Kingdom (Not explicitly stated; (P \u2192 R)\n    (Some sophists reason; does not force God to reason.)\n    If God reasons, then God can distinguish truth from falsehood. (R \u2192 D)\n    If God can distinguish truth from falsehood, then God is not morally perfect. (D \u2192 \u00acM)\n    God is morally perfect. (M is True)\n    God is a sophist.         "rationale": "<nl_cot>\nLet's analyze the premises step by step to see if we can determine the truth of the conclusion.\n\n1. **Premise 1:** All people who eat salads regularly are very conscious about their health and eating habits.\n2. **Premise 2:** All people who grew up in health-conscious childhood homes eat salads regularly.\n3. **Premise 3:** All people who fulfill their daily nutritional intakes grew up in health-conscious childhood homes.\n4. **Premise 4:** All people who disregard their physical well-being are not very conscious about their health and eating habits.\n5. **Premise 5:** If people visit the gym at least once a day, then they always fulfill their daily nutritional intakes.\n6. **Premise 6:** Taylor either grew up in a health-conscious childhood home and disregard her physical well-being, or she did neither.\n\nLet's break down the logical structure of these premises and the conclusion.\n\n- From Premise 2, if Taylor grew up in a health-conscious childhood home, then Taylor eats salads regularly (by Premise 2).\n- From Premise 1, if Taylor eats salads regularly, then Taylor is very conscious about her health and eating habits.\n- From Premise 4, if Taylor disregards her physical well-being, then Taylor is not very conscious about her health and eating habits.\n- From Premise 5, if Taylor visits the gym at least once a day, then she fulfills her daily nutritional intakes.\n- From Premise 3, if Taylor fulfills her daily nutritional intakes, then Taylor grew up in a health-conscious childhood home.\n\nNow, let's consider the conclusion: Taylor neither grew up in a health-conscious childhood home nor does she visit the gym at least once a day.\n\n- If Taylor did not grow up in a health-conscious childhood home, then from Premise 2, Taylor does not eat salads regularly.\n- If Taylor does not eat salads regularly, then from Premise 1, Taylor is not very conscious about her health and eating habits.\n- If Taylor is not very conscious about her health and eating habits, then from Premise 4, Taylor does not disregard her physical well-being (because the contrapositive of this statement is true: if Taylor disregards her physical well-being, then she is not very conscious about her health and eating habits).\n\nThis means that if Taylor did not grow up in a health-conscious childhood home, she must visit the gym at least once a day (from the contrapositive of Premise 5: if Taylor does not visit the gym at least once a day, then she does not fulfill her daily nutritional intakes, and if she does not fulfill her daily nutritional intakes, then she did not grow up in a health-conscious childhood home).\n\nTherefore, the only way for Taylor to satisfy all the premises is if she grew up in a health-conscious childhood home and visits the gym at least once a day. This directly contradicts the conclusion that Taylor neither grew up in a health-conscious childhood home nor does she visit the gym at least once a day.\n\nThus, the conclusion is false.\n</nl_cot>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (B).\n</answer>",

    {
        "premises": "The summer Olympic games is a sporting event. \nThe last summer Olympic games was in Tokyo.\nThe United States won the most medals in Tokyo. ",
        "conclusions": "The last summer Olympic games were not in Tokyo.",
        "rationale": "Let's analyze the given premises and the conclusion step by step.\n\nPremises:\n1. The summer Olympic games is a sporting event.\n2. The last summer Olympic games was in Tokyo.\n3. The United States won the most medals in Tokyo.\n\nConclusion to Evaluate:\n- The last summer Olympic games were not in Tokyo.\n\nFrom Premise 2, we directly know that the last summer Olympic games were indeed in Tokyo. This premise provides a clear and definitive statement about the location of the last summer Olympic games.\n\nThe conclusion states the opposite, which contradicts Premise 2.\n\nTherefore, based on the given premises, the conclusion is false.\n\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (B).\n</answer>",

Do not include any additional commentary or information outside of these tags.\n\n\nBelow are three examples that demonstrate the desired style:\n\n<EXAMPLE 1>\n<premises>\nPeter Parker is either a superhero or a civilian.\nThe Hulk is a destroyer.\nThe Hulk wakes up when he is angry.\nIf the Hulk wakes up, then he will break a bridge.\nThor is a god.\nThor will break a bridge when he is happy.\nA god is not a destroyer.\nPeter Parker wears a uniform when he is a superhero.\nPeter Parker is not a civilian if a destroyer is breaking a bridge.\nIf Thor is happy, the Hulk is angry.\n</premises>\n<conclusion>\nIf Thor is happy, then Peter Parker wears a uniform.\n</conclusion>\n<question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker wears a uniform.\n</question> \n<options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</options>\n<truth_table>\nLet:\n    T: Thor is happy\n    H: The Hulk is angry\n    A: The Hulk wakes up\n    B: A bridge is broken\n    C: Peter Parker is a civilian\n    S: Peter Parker is a superhero\n    U: Peter Parker wears a uniform\nPremises:\n    S \u2228 C\n    The Hulk is a destroyer (assumed true)\n    H \u2192 A\n    A \u2192 B\n    Thor is a god\n    T \u2192 B\n    A god is not a destroyer\n    S \u2192 U\n    B \u2192 \u00acC\n    T \u2192 H\nLogical chain (assuming T = True):\n    T = True\n    \u2192 From (10): H = True\n    H = True\n    \u2192 From (3): A = True\n    A = True\n    \u2192 From (4): B = True\n    B = True and given Hulk is a destroyer\n    \u2192 From (9): C = False\n    From (1): S \u2228 C must be true; since C is False, S = True\n    S = True\n    \u2192 From (8): U = True\nTruth Table (for T = True):\n| T (Thor is happy) | H (The Hulk is angry) | A (The Hulk wakes up) | B (A bridge is broken) | C (Peter Parker is a civilian) | S (Peter Parker is a superhero) | U (Peter Parker wears a uniform) |\n|-------------------|-----------------------|-----------------------|------------------------|---------------------------------|-----------------------------------|-----------------------------------|\n| True              | True                  | True                  | True                   | False                           | True                              | True                              |\n</truth_table>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (A).\n</answer>\n</EXAMPLE 1>\n\n<EXAMPLE 2>\n<premises>\nAll philosophers reason.\nSome sophists reason.\nAll who can reason can distinguish truth from falsehood.\nNobody who can distinguish truth from falsehood is morally perfect.\nThe theistic God is morally perfect.\nThe theistic God is a sophist.\n</premises>\n<conclusion>\nThe theistic God is a sophist and a philosopher.\n</conclusion>\n<question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? The theistic God is a sophist and a philosopher.\n</question>\n<options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</options>\n<truth_table>\nLet:\n    P: God is a philosopher\n    R: God reasons\n    D: God can distinguish truth from falsehood\n    M: God is morally perfect\n    S: God is a sophist\nPremises for God:\n    If God is a philosopher, then God reasons. (P \u2192 R)\n    (Some sophists reason; does not force God to reason.)\n    If God reasons, then God can distinguish truth from falsehood. (R \u2192 D)\n    If God can distinguish truth from falsehood, then God is not morally perfect. (D \u2192 \u00acM)\n    God is morally perfect. (M is True)\n    God is a sophist. (S is True)\nLogical chain:\n    From (5) M = True.\n    From (4), if D were True then M would be False; therefore, D must be False.\n    From (3), if R were True then D would be True; therefore, R must be False.\n    From (1), if P were True then R would be True; therefore, P must be False.\n    Given (6), S = True.\nTruth Table (for god):\n| P (Philosopher) | R (Reasons) | D (Distinguishes truth) | M (Morally Perfect) | S (Sophist) | S \u2227 P (Sophist and Philosopher) |\n|-----------------|-------------|-------------------------|---------------------|-------------|---------------------------------|\n| False           | False       | False                   | True                | True        | False                           |\n</truth_table>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (B).\n</answer>\n</EXAMPLE 2>\n\n<EXAMPLE 3>\n<premises>\nWilliam Dickinson was a British politician who sat in the House of Commons William Dickinson attended Westminster school for high school and then the University of Edinburgh. \nThe University of Edinburgh is a university located in the United Kingdom. \nWilliam Dickinson supported the Portland Whigs. \nPeople who supported the Portland Whigs did not get a seat in the Parliament.\n</premises>\n<conclusion>\nWilliam Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university.\n</conclusion>\n<question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? William Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university.\n</question> \n<options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</options>\n<truth_table>\nLet:\n    W: William Dickinson attended Westminster School for high school.\n    E: William Dickinson attended the University of Edinburgh.\n    U: The University of Edinburgh is located in the United Kingdom (Given explicitly, so U = True).\n    L: Westminster School is located in the United Kingdom (Not explicitly stated; although implied by context, it remains uncertain.\n    Therefore, since U = True but L is uncertain, the conjunction L \u2227 U is uncertain.\nTruth Table (Key Possibilities):\n| L (Westminster School in UK) | U (University of Edinburgh in UK) | L \u2227 U (Both in UK) |\n|------------------------------|------------------------------------|--------------------|\n| True                         | True                               | True               |\n| False                        | True                               | False              |\n</truth_table>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (C).\n</answer>\n</EXAMPLE 3>\n\n\nThe following is the problem you need to solve.\n\n<premises>\nSusan flies to LGA airport.\nThe departure and arrival can not be at the same airport.\nJohn flies from LGA airport.\n</premises>\n<conclusion>\nSusan flies from LGA airport.\n</conclusion>\n<question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain?         "premises": "No one nice to animals is also mean to animals.\nSome grumpy people are mean to animals.\nAll animal lovers are nice to animals.\nAll pet owners love animals.\nTom is a pet owner.",
        "conclusions": "Tom is not both a grumpy person and mean to animals.",
        "rationale": "<nl_cot>\nLet's break down the premises and analyze them step by step.\n\n1. **No one nice to animals is also mean to animals.**\n   - This can be expressed as: If someone is nice to animals, then they are not mean to animals. Formally, \\( N(x) \\rightarrow \\neg M(x) \\), where \\( N(x) \\) means \\( x \\) is nice to animals and \\( M(x) \\) means \\( x \\) is mean to animals.\n\n2. **Some grumpy people are mean to animals.**\n   - This means there exists at least one grumpy person who is mean to animals. Formally, \\( \\exists x (G(x) \\land M(x)) \\), where \\( G(x) \\) means \\( x \\) is grumpy.\n\n3. **All animal lovers are nice to animals.**\n   - This can be expressed as: If someone is an animal lover, then they are nice to animals. Formally, \\( A(x) \\rightarrow N(x) \\), where \\( A(x) \\) means \\( x \\) is an animal lover.\n\n4. **All pet owners love animals.**\n   - This can be expressed as: If someone is a pet owner, then they love animals. Formally, \\( P(x) \\rightarrow A(x) \\), where \\( P(x) \\) means \\( x \\) is a pet owner.\n\n5. **Tom is a pet owner.**\n   - This means \\( P(Tom) \\) is true.\n\nNow, we need to determine if Tom is not both a grumpy person and mean to animals, i.e., \\( \\neg (G(Tom) \\land M(Tom)) \\).\n\nFrom premise 4, since Tom is a pet owner, we have \\( P(Tom) \\rightarrow A(Tom) \\). This means \\( A(Tom) \\) is true. From premise 3, since \\( A(Tom) \\) is true, we have \\( A(Tom) \\rightarrow N(Tom) \\), which means \\( N(Tom) \\) is true.\n\nSince \\( N(Tom) \\) is true, according to premise 1, \\( M(Tom) \\) must be false. Therefore, Tom cannot be mean to animals.\n\nSince \\( M(Tom) \\) is false, the statement \\( G(Tom) \\land M(Tom) \\) is false because it requires both \\( G(Tom) \\) and \\( M(Tom) \\) to be true, but \\( M(Tom) \\) is false.\n\nThus, the statement \\( \\neg (G(Tom) \\land M(Tom)) \\) is true.\n</nl_cot>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (A).\n</answer>",
        "label": "True",
        "predict": "True",

Do not include any additional commentary or information outside of these tags.\n\n\nBelow are three examples that demonstrate the desired style:\n\n<EXAMPLE 1>\n<premises>\nPeter Parker is either a superhero or a civilian.\nThe Hulk is a destroyer.\nThe Hulk wakes up when he is angry.\nIf the Hulk wakes up, then he will break a bridge.\nThor is a god.\nThor will break a bridge when he is happy.\nA god is not a destroyer.\nPeter Parker wears a uniform when he is a superhero.\nPeter Parker is not a civilian if a destroyer is breaking a bridge.\nIf Thor is happy, the Hulk is angry.\n</premises>\n<conclusion>\nIf Thor is happy, then Peter Parker wears a uniform.\n</conclusion>\n<question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker wears a uniform.\n</question> \n<options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</options>\n<truth_table>\nLet:\n    T: Thor is happy\n    H: The Hulk is angry\n    A: The Hulk wakes up\n    B: A bridge is broken\n    C: Peter Parker is a civilian\n    S: Peter Parker is a superhero\n    U: Peter Parker wears a uniform\nPremises:\n    S \u2228 C\n    The Hulk is a destroyer (assumed true)\n    H \u2192 A\n    A \u2192 B\n    Thor is a god\n    T \u2192 B\n    A god is not a destroyer\n    S \u2192 U\n    B \u2192 \u00acC\n    T \u2192 H\nLogical chain (assuming T = True):\n    T = True\n    \u2192 From (10): H = True\n    H = True\n    \u2192 From (3): A = True\n    A = True\n    \u2192 From (4): B = True\n    B = True and given Hulk is a destroyer\n    \u2192 From (9): C = False\n    From (1): S \u2228 C must be true; since C is False, S = True\n    S = True\n    \u2192 From (8): U = True\nTruth Table (for T = True):\n| T (Thor is happy) | H (The Hulk is angry) | A (The Hulk wakes up) | B (A bridge is broken) | C (Peter Parker is a civilian) | S (Peter Parker is a superhero) | U (Peter Parker wears a uniform) |\n|-------------------|-----------------------|-----------------------|------------------------|---------------------------------|-----------------------------------|-----------------------------------|\n| True              | True                  | True                  | True                   | False                           | True                              | True                              |\n</truth_table>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (A).\n</answer>\n</EXAMPLE 1>\n\n<EXAMPLE 2>\n<premises>\nAll philosophers reason.\nSome sophists reason.\nAll who can reason can distinguish truth from falsehood.\nNobody who can distinguish truth from falsehood is morally perfect.\nThe theistic God is morally perfect.\nThe theistic God is a sophist.\n</premises>\n<conclusion>\nThe theistic God is a sophist and a philosopher.\n</conclusion>\n<question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? The theistic God is a sophist and a philosopher.\n</question>\n<options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</options>\n<truth_table>\nLet:\n    P: God is a philosopher\n    R: God reasons\n    D: God can distinguish truth from falsehood\n    M: God is morally perfect\n    S: God is a sophist\nPremises for God:\n    If God is a philosopher, then God reasons. (P \u2192 R)\n    (Some sophists reason; does not force God to reason.)\n    If God reasons, then God can distinguish truth from falsehood. (R \u2192 D)\n    If God can distinguish truth from falsehood, then God is not morally perfect. (D \u2192 \u00acM)\n    God is morally perfect. (M is True)\n    God is a sophist. (S is True)\nLogical chain:\n    From (5) M = True.\n    From (4), if D were True then M would be False; therefore, D must be False.\n    From (3), if R were True then D would be True; therefore, R must be False.\n    From (1), if P were True then R would be True; therefore, P must be False.\n    Given (6), S = True.\nTruth Table (for god):\n| P (Philosopher) | R (Reasons) | D (Distinguishes truth) | M (Morally Perfect) | S (Sophist) | S \u2227 P (Sophist and Philosopher) |\n|-----------------|-------------|-------------------------|---------------------|-------------|---------------------------------|\n| False           | False       | False                   | True                | True        | False                           |\n</truth_table>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (B).\n</answer>\n</EXAMPLE 2>\n\n<EXAMPLE 3>\n<premises>\nWilliam Dickinson was a British politician who sat in the House of Commons William Dickinson attended Westminster school for high school and then the University of Edinburgh. \nThe University of Edinburgh is a university located in the United Kingdom. \nWilliam Dickinson supported the Portland Whigs. \nPeople who supported the Portland Whigs did not get a seat in the Parliament.\n</premises>\n<conclusion>\nWilliam Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university.\n</conclusion>\n<question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? William Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university.\n</question> \n<options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</options>\n<truth_table>\nLet:\n    W: William Dickinson attended Westminster School for high school.\n    E: William Dickinson attended the University of Edinburgh.\n    U: The University of Edinburgh is located in the United Kingdom (Given explicitly, so U = True).\n    L: Westminster School is located in the United Kingdom (Not explicitly stated; although implied by context, it remains uncertain.\n    Therefore, since U = True but L is uncertain, the conjunction L \u2227 U is uncertain.\nTruth Table (Key Possibilities):\n| L (Westminster School in UK) | U (University of Edinburgh in UK) | L \u2227 U (Both in UK) |\n|------------------------------|------------------------------------|--------------------|\n| True                         | True                               | True               |\n| False                        | True                               | False              |\n</truth_table>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (C).\n</answer>\n</EXAMPLE 3>\n\n\nThe following is the problem you need to solve.\n\n<premises>\nNo one nice to animals is also mean to animals.\nSome grumpy people are mean to animals.\nAll animal lovers are nice to animals.\nAll pet owners love animals.\nTom is a pet owner.\n</premises>\n<conclusion>\nTom is not both a grumpy person and mean to animals.\n</conclusion>\n<question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain?         "premises": "No one nice to animals is also mean to animals.\nSome grumpy people are mean to animals.\nAll animal lovers are nice to animals.\nAll pet owners love animals.\nTom is a pet owner.",
        "conclusions": "If Tom is not both a grumpy person and mean to animals, then Tom is neither a grumpy person nor an animal lover.",
        "rationale": "<nl_cot>\nLet's break down the premises and the conclusion step-by-step:\n\n1. No one nice to animals is also mean to animals.\n   - This means if someone is nice to animals, then they are not mean to animals.\n2. Some grumpy people are mean to animals.\n   - This means there exists at least one grumpy person who is mean to animals.\n3. All animal lovers are nice to animals.\n   - This means if someone is an animal lover, then they are nice to animals.\n4. All pet owners love animals.\n   - This means if someone is a pet owner, then they love animals.\n5. Tom is a pet owner.\n   - This means Tom loves animals and, by the previous premise, is an animal lover.\n\nNow, let's analyze the conclusion:\n- If Tom is not both a grumpy person and mean to animals, then Tom is neither a grumpy person nor an animal lover.\n\nGiven that Tom is a pet owner, he is an animal lover and nice to animals. Therefore, Tom cannot be mean to animals because all animal lovers are nice to animals (premise 3). \n\nIf Tom is not mean to animals, and from premise 1, no one who is nice to animals is mean to animals, this means Tom is not grumpy (because if Tom were grumpy and mean to animals, he would contradict the premises). \n\nTherefore, if Tom is not both a grumpy person and mean to animals, he must be neither grumpy nor an animal lover (since he is already an animal lover, the only way he can satisfy the condition is if he is not a grumpy person).\n\nThis means the conclusion logically follows from the premises.\n</nl_cot>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (A).\n</answer>",

since C is False, S = True\n    S = True\n    \u2192 From (8): U = True\nTruth Table (for T = True):\n| T (Thor is happy) | H (The Hulk is angry) | A (The Hulk wakes up) | B (A bridge is broken) | C (Peter Parker is a civilian) | S (Peter Parker is a superhero) | U (Peter Parker wears a uniform) |\n|-------------------|-----------------------|-----------------------|------------------------|---------------------------------|-----------------------------------|-----------------------------------|\n| True              | True                  | True                  | True                   | False                           | True                              | True                              |\n</truth_table>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (A).\n</answer>\n</EXAMPLE 1>\n\n<EXAMPLE 2>\n<premises>\nAll philosophers reason.\nSome sophists reason.\nAll who can reason can distinguish truth from falsehood.\nNobody who can distinguish truth from falsehood is morally perfect.\nThe theistic God is morally perfect.\nThe theistic God is a sophist.\n</premises>\n<conclusion>\nThe theistic God is a sophist and a philosopher.\n</conclusion>\n<question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? The theistic God is a sophist and a philosopher.\n</question>\n<options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</options>\n<truth_table>\nLet:\n    P: God is a philosopher\n    R: God reasons\n    D: God can distinguish truth from falsehood\n    M: God is morally perfect\n    S: God is a sophist\nPremises for God:\n    If God is a philosopher, then God reasons. (P \u2192 R)\n    (Some sophists reason; does not force God to reason.)\n    If God reasons, then God can distinguish truth from falsehood. (R \u2192 D)\n    If God can distinguish truth from falsehood, then God is not morally perfect. (D \u2192 \u00acM)\n    God is morally perfect. (M is True)\n    God is a sophist. (S is True)\nLogical chain:\n    From (5) M = True.\n    From (4), if D were True then M would be False; therefore, D must be False.\n    From (3), if R were True then D would be True; therefore, R must be False.\n    From (1), if P were True then R would be True; therefore, P must be False.\n    Given (6), S = True.\nTruth Table (for god):\n| P (Philosopher) | R (Reasons) | D (Distinguishes truth) | M (Morally Perfect) | S (Sophist) | S \u2227 P (Sophist and Philosopher) |\n|-----------------|-------------|-------------------------|---------------------|-------------|---------------------------------|\n| False           | False       | False                   | True                | True        | False                           |\n</truth_table>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (B).\n</answer>\n</EXAMPLE 2>\n\n<EXAMPLE 3>\n<premises>\nWilliam Dickinson was a British politician who sat in the House of Commons William Dickinson attended Westminster school for high school and then the University of Edinburgh. \nThe University of Edinburgh is a university located in the United Kingdom. \nWilliam Dickinson supported the Portland Whigs. \nPeople who supported the Portland Whigs did not get a seat in the Parliament.\n</premises>\n<conclusion>\nWilliam Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university.\n</conclusion>\n<question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? Therefore, Yuri cannot do jump shots (since not activating leg muscles implies not being able to do jump shots, based on the logical flow of the premises).\n\nPremise 2 states that all professional basketball players can do jump shots.     {
        "premises": "Some professional basketball players are not American nationals.\nAll professional basketball players can do jump shots.\nIf someone can jump shots, they leap straight into the air.\nIf someone leaps straight into the air, they activate their leg muscles. \nYuri does not activate his leg muscles.",
        "conclusions": "Yuri is not an American professional basketball player.",
        "rationale": "<nl_cot>\nLet's analyze the premises step by step to determine if the conclusion logically follows.\n\n1. **Premise 1**: Some professional basketball players are not American nationals.\n2. **Premise 2**: All professional basketball players can do jump shots.\n3. **Premise 3**: If someone can jump shots, they leap straight into the air.\n4. **Premise 4**: If someone leaps straight into the air, they activate their leg muscles.\n5. **Premise 5**: Yuri does not activate his leg muscles.\n\nFrom Premise 4, we can infer:\n- If someone leaps straight into the air, they activate their leg muscles. (L \u2192 A, where L is leaping straight into the air and A is activating leg muscles)\n\nFrom Premise 3, we can infer:\n- If someone can jump shots, they leap straight into the air. (J \u2192 L, where J is being able to do jump shots and L is leaping straight into the air)\n\nCombining Premises 2 and 3, we get:\n- If someone is a professional basketball player, they can jump shots, and if they can jump shots, they leap straight into the air. (P \u2192 J \u2192 L, where P is being a professional basketball player)\n\nSince Yuri does not activate his leg muscles (\u00acA), we can infer from Premise 4 that he did not leap straight into the air (\u00acL).\n\nFrom Premise 3, if someone did not leap straight into the air, they cannot have jumped shots (\u00acL \u2192 \u00acJ).\n\nFrom Premise 2, if someone did not jump shots, they cannot be a professional basketball player (\u00acJ \u2192 \u00acP).\n\nTherefore, Yuri is not a professional basketball player (\u00acP).\n\nHowever, Premise 1 states that some professional basketball players are not American nationals, which means there exist non-American professional basketball players. This does not provide any information about Yuri's nationality.\n\nSince we have determined that Yuri is not a professional basketball player, the statement \"Yuri is not an American professional basketball player\" is true because Yuri is not a professional basketball player at all.\n</nl_cot>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (A).\n</answer>",

2:** All professional basketball players can do jump shots.\n3. **Premise 3:** If someone can jump shots, they leap straight into the air.\n4. **Premise 4:** If someone leaps straight into the air, they activate their leg muscles.\n5. **Premise 5:** Yuri does not activate his leg muscles.\n\nFrom these premises, we can derive the following logical implications:\n\n- From Premise 2 and Premise 3, we can infer that all professional basketball players leap straight into the air because they can do jump shots.\n- From Premise 3 and Premise 4, we can infer that all professional basketball players activate their leg muscles because they leap straight into the air.\n- Since Yuri does not activate his leg muscles (Premise 5), Yuri cannot be a professional basketball player because professional basketball players must activate their leg muscles.\n\nNow, we need to evaluate the conclusion: \"If Yuri does not leap straight into the air, then Yuri is an American professional basketball player.\"\n\nSince we have already established that Yuri cannot be a professional basketball player (because he does not activate his leg muscles, and professional basketball players must activate their leg muscles), the statement \"If Yuri does not leap straight into the air, then Yuri is an American professional basketball player\" can be analyzed as follows:\n\n- If Yuri does not leap straight into the air, it implies that he does not do jump shots (since all professional basketball players who can do jump shots must leap straight into the air).\n- Since Yuri is not a professional basketball player (as he does not activate his leg muscles), the statement \"Yuri is an American professional basketball player\" is not relevant because he is not a professional basketball player at all.\n\nThus, the conclusion is vacuously true because the antecedent (\"Yuri does not leap straight into the air\") implies that Yuri is not a professional basketball player, and the statement about         "rationale": "Let:\n    A: Yuri is an American professional basketball player.\n    J: Yuri can do jump shots.\n    L: Yuri leaps straight into the air.\n    M: Yuri activates his leg muscles.\nPremises:\n    Some professional basketball players are not American nationals. (Existential statement; does not directly affect Yuri's status but sets a context.)\n    All professional basketball players can do jump shots. (J \u2192 A)\n    If someone can jump shots, they leap straight into the air. (J \u2192 L)\n    If someone leaps straight into the air, they activate their leg muscles. (L \u2192 M)\n    Yuri does not activate his leg muscles. (\u00acM)\nConclusion to Evaluate:\n    If Yuri is not an American professional basketball player, then Yuri is a professional basketball player. (\u00acA \u2192 J)\nLogical Chain:\n    From (4), \u00acM is given.\n    From (3) and (4), \u00acL (since \u00acM \u2192 \u00acL, by contraposition).\n    From (2) and (3), \u00acJ (since \u00acL \u2192 \u00acJ, by contraposition).\n    From (1) and (2), \u00acA (since \u00acJ \u2192 \u00acA, by contraposition).\n    Therefore, if \u00acA is true, then J must be true, which aligns with the conclusion.\nTruth Table:\n| A (American) | J (Can do jump shots) | L (Leaps straight into the air) | M (Activates leg muscles) |\n|--------------|-----------------------|---------------------------------|---------------------------|\n| True         | True                  | True                            | True                      |\n| True         | False                 | False                           | False                     |\n| False        | True                  | True                            | False                     |\n| False        | False                 | False                           | False                     |\nFrom the truth table, if \u00acA is true, then J must be true, which directly supports the conclusion \u00acA \u2192 J.\n</truth_table>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (A).\n</answer>",

since C is False, S = True\n    S = True\n    \u2192 From (8): U = True\nTruth Table (for T = True):\n| T (Thor is happy) | H (The Hulk is angry) | A (The Hulk wakes up) | B (A bridge is broken) | C (Peter Parker is a civilian) | S (Peter Parker is a superhero) | U (Peter Parker wears a uniform) |\n|-------------------|-----------------------|-----------------------|------------------------|---------------------------------|-----------------------------------|-----------------------------------|\n| True              | True                  | True                  | True                   | False                           | True                              | True                              |\n</truth_table>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (A).\n</answer>\n</EXAMPLE 1>\n\n<EXAMPLE 2>\n<premises>\nAll philosophers reason.\nSome sophists reason.\nAll who can reason can distinguish truth from falsehood.\nNobody who can distinguish truth from falsehood is morally perfect.\nThe theistic God is morally perfect.\nThe theistic God is a sophist.\n</premises>\n<conclusion>\nThe theistic God is a sophist and a philosopher.\n</conclusion>\n<question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? The theistic God is a sophist and a philosopher.\n</question>\n<options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</options>\n<truth_table>\nLet:\n    P: God is a philosopher\n    R: God reasons\n    D: God can distinguish truth from falsehood\n    M: God is morally perfect\n    S: God is a sophist\nPremises for God:\n    If God is a philosopher, then God reasons. (P \u2192 R)\n    (Some sophists reason; does not force God to reason.)\n    If God reasons, then God can distinguish truth from falsehood. (R \u2192 D)\n    If God can distinguish truth from falsehood, then God is not morally perfect. (D \u2192 \u00acM)\n    God is morally perfect. (M is True)\n    God is a sophist. (S is True)\nLogical chain:\n    From (5) M = True.\n    From (4), if D were True then M would be False; therefore, D must be False.\n    From (3), if R were True then D would be True; therefore, R must be False.\n    From (1), if P were True then R would be True; therefore, P must be False.\n    Given (6), S = True.\nTruth Table (for god):\n| P (Philosopher) | R (Reasons) | D (Distinguishes truth) | M (Morally Perfect) | S (Sophist) | S \u2227 P (Sophist and Philosopher) |\n|-----------------|-------------|-------------------------|---------------------|-------------|---------------------------------|\n| False           | False       | False                   | True                | True        | False                           |\n</truth_table>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (B).\n</answer>\n</EXAMPLE 2>\n\n<EXAMPLE 3>\n<premises>\nWilliam Dickinson was a British politician who sat in the House of Commons William Dickinson attended Westminster school for high school and then the University of Edinburgh. \nThe University of Edinburgh is a university located in the United Kingdom. \nWilliam Dickinson supported the Portland Whigs. \nPeople who supported the Portland Whigs did not get a seat in the Parliament.\n</premises>\n<conclusion>\nWilliam Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university.\n</conclusion>\n<question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? (\u2200x S(x))\nLogical Chain:\n    From the first premise, we know every event is either happy or sad, which means there are no events that are neither happy nor sad.\n    From the second premise, we know there exists at least one event that is happy.\n    If there exists at least one event that is happy, then it cannot be true that all events are sad because if all events were sad, there could not be any happy events.\nTruth Table (Simplified since we are dealing with logical implications rather than a truth table for multiple propositions):\n| H (Event is happy) | S (Event is sad) | \u2203x H(x) (At least one event is happy) | \u2200x S(x) (All events are sad) |\n|--------------------|------------------|--------------------------------------|------------------------------|\n| True               | True             | True                                 | False                        |\n| True               | False            | True                                 | False                        |\n| False              | True             | False                                | True                         |\n| False              | False            | False                                | True                         |\n</truth_table>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (B).\n</answer>",

        "conclusions": "KiKi is a barking dog.",
        "rationale": "<nl_cot>\nLet's analyze the premises step by step to determine if KiKi is a barking dog.\n\n1. **Premise 1:** Jane does not like any animals that bark.\n2. **Premise 2:** All dogs are animals that bark.\n3. **Premise 3:** Jane likes all animals that jump.\n4. **Premise 4:** If an animal has legs, then it jumps.\n5. **Premise 5:** If an animal is terricolous, then it has legs.\n6. **Premise 6:** KiKi is an animal.\n7. **Premise 7:** If KiKi neither jumps nor has legs, then KiKi is terricolous or has legs.\n\nFrom Premise 2 and Premise 1, we can infer that if KiKi were a dog, it would be a barking animal that Jane does not like. However, we need to determine if KiKi is a dog.\n\nTo determine if KiKi is a dog, we need to consider the implications of the premises related to jumping and legs:\n- From Premise 4 and Premise 5, we know that if an animal has legs, it jumps, and if an animal is terricolous, it has legs. Therefore, an animal that is terricolous and has legs will jump.\n- Premise 7 states that if KiKi neither jumps nor has legs, then KiKi is either terricolous or has legs.\n\nLet's analyze the implications of KiKi not having legs:\n- If KiKi does not have legs, then according to Premise 4, it cannot jump.\n- According to Premise 7, if KiKi does not jump and does not have legs, it must be either terricolous or have legs. Since we assumed it does not have legs, it must be terricolous.\n\nNow, let's consider if KiKi can be a dog:\n- If KiKi is a dog, it would be a barking animal. However, we need to check if KiKi can be a dog while satisfying the conditions derived from the other premises.\n- Since dogs bark and Jane does not like barking animals, if KiKi were a dog, it would be a barking animal that Jane does not like. But we need to check if KiKi can be a dog while satisfying the conditions of not jumping or having legs.\n\nGiven that KiKi is an animal, and it could be terricolous (which means it has legs), or it could be an animal that does not have legs and jumps. Since dogs are specifically mentioned as animals that bark, and Jane does not like barking animals, KiKi cannot be a dog if it does not have legs and does not jump, as it would be terricolous, which means it has legs, and thus would jump.\n\nTherefore, KiKi cannot be a barking dog because if it were a dog, it would be a barking animal that Jane does not like, and it would have to have legs and jump, which contradicts the conditions given in the premises.\n\n</nl_cot>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (B).\n</answer>",

        "premises": "Jane does not like any animals that bark.\nAll dogs are animals that bark.\nJane likes all animals that jump.\nIf an animal has legs, then it jumps.\nIf an animal is terricolous, then it has legs. \nKiKi is an animal.\nIf KiKi neither jumps nor has legs, then KiKi is terricolous or has legs.",

        "rationale": "<nl_cot>\nLet's break down the premises and see what we can deduce about KiKi.\n\n1. Jane does not like any animals that bark.\n2. All dogs are animals that bark.\n3. Jane likes all animals that jump.\n4. If an animal has legs, then it jumps.\n5. If an animal is terricolous, then it has legs.\n6. KiKi is an animal.\n7. If KiKi neither jumps nor has legs, then KiKi is terricolous or has legs.\n\nFrom premise 2, all dogs bark. From premise 1, Jane does not like any animals that bark. However, this does not give us direct information about KiKi unless we know if KiKi is a dog or not.\n\nFrom premise 3, Jane likes all animals that jump. From premise 4, if an animal has legs, then it jumps. Premise 5 states that if an animal is terricolous, then it has legs. \n\nPremise 6 states that KiKi is an animal. Premise 7 states that if KiKi neither jumps nor has legs, then KiKi is terricolous or has legs. This means if KiKi does not jump, it must have legs (or be terricolous, which implies it has legs).\n\nNow, let's consider the conclusion:\n- KiKi does not bark\n- KiKi is not a dog\n\nFrom premise 2, all dogs bark. Therefore, if KiKi is a dog, KiKi barks. From premise 1, Jane does not like any animals that bark, but this does not directly impact KiKi unless KiKi is a dog. So, KiKi not barking does not necessarily mean KiKi is not a dog; it could be that KiKi is not a dog.\n\nFrom premise 6, KiKi is an animal. To determine if KiKi is a dog, we need to check if KiKi can be an animal that barks. Since all dogs bark and Jane does not like any animals that bark, if KiKi barks, KiKi cannot be a dog. If KiKi does not bark, KiKi could potentially be a dog or some other animal that does not bark.\n\nGiven the information, KiKi not barking does not definitively mean KiKi is not a dog, but it is consistent with KiKi not being a dog. However, we cannot definitively conclude that KiKi is not a dog based on the premises alone.\n\nSince KiKi not barking does not definitively mean KiKi is not a dog, the statement \"KiKi does not bark and he is not a dog\" is uncertain.\n</nl_cot>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (C).\n</answer>",

(P \u2192 R)\n    (Some sophists reason; does not force God to reason.)\n    If God reasons, then God can distinguish truth from falsehood. (R \u2192 D)\n    If God can distinguish truth from falsehood, then God is not morally perfect. (D \u2192 \u00acM)\n    God is morally perfect. (M is True)\n    God is a sophist. (S is True)\nLogical chain:\n    From (5) M = True.\n    From (4), if D were True then M would be False; therefore, D must be False.\n    From (3), if R were True then D would be True; therefore, R must be False.\n    From (1), if P were True then R would be True; therefore, P must be False.\n    Given (6), S = True.\nTruth Table (for god):\n| P (Philosopher) | R (Reasons) | D (Distinguishes truth) | M (Morally Perfect) | S (Sophist) | S \u2227 P (Sophist and Philosopher) |\n|-----------------|-------------|-------------------------|---------------------|-------------|---------------------------------|\n| False           | False       | False                   | True                | True        | False                           |\n</truth_table>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (B).\n</answer>\n</EXAMPLE 2>\n\n<EXAMPLE 3>\n<premises>\nWilliam Dickinson was a British politician who sat in the House of Commons William Dickinson attended Westminster school for high school and then the University of Edinburgh. \nThe University of Edinburgh is a university located in the United Kingdom. \nWilliam Dickinson supported the Portland Whigs. \nPeople who supported the Portland Whigs did not get a seat in the Parliament.\n</premises>\n<conclusion>\nWilliam Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university.\n</conclusion>\n<question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? William Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university.\n</question> \n<options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</options>\n<truth_table>\nLet:\n    W: William Dickinson attended Westminster School for high school.\n    E: William Dickinson attended the University of Edinburgh.\n    U: The University of Edinburgh is located in the United Kingdom (Given explicitly, so U = True).\n    L: Westminster School is located in the United Kingdom (Not explicitly stated; uncertain).\nPremises:\n    William Dickinson attended Westminster School for high school and then the University of Edinburgh.\n    The University of Edinburgh is a university located in the United Kingdom.\n    William Dickinson supported the Portland Whigs.\n    People who supported the Portland Whigs did not get a seat in the Parliament.\nConclusion to Evaluate: \n    William Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university, which translates to L \u2227 U.\nLogical Chain:\n    From (2), we know U = True.\n    However, L is not explicitly given by the premises; although implied by context, it remains uncertain.\n    Therefore, since U = True but L is uncertain, the conjunction L \u2227 U is uncertain.\nTruth Table (Key Possibilities):\n| L (Westminster School in UK) | U (University of Edinburgh in UK) | L \u2227 U (Both in UK) |\n|------------------------------|------------------------------------|--------------------|\n| True                         | True                               | True               |\n| False                        | True                               | False              |\n</truth_table>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (C).\n</answer>\n</EXAMPLE 3>\n\n\nThe following is the problem you need to solve.\n\n<premises>\nAilton Silva, born in 1995, is commonly known as Ailton.\nAilton is a football player who was loaned out to Braga.\nAilton Silva is a Brazilian footballer who plays for N\u00e1utico.\nN\u00e1utico is a football club along with Braga.\nFluminense is a football club.\n</premises>\n<conclusion>\nAilton Silva does not play for a football club.\n</conclusion>\n<question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? (P \u2192 R)\n    (Some sophists reason; does not force God to reason.)\n    If God reasons, then God can distinguish truth from falsehood. (R \u2192 D)\n    If God can distinguish truth from falsehood, then God is not morally perfect. (D \u2192 \u00acM)\n    God is morally perfect. (M is True)\n    God is a sophist. (S is True)\nLogical chain:\n    From (5) M = True.\n    From (4), if D were True then M would be False; therefore, D must be False.\n    From (3), if R were True then D would be True; therefore, R must be False.\n    From (1), if P were True then R would be True; therefore, P must be False.\n    Given (6), S = True.\nTruth Table (for god):\n| P (Philosopher) | R (Reasons) | D (Distinguishes truth) | M (Morally Perfect) | S (Sophist) | S \u2227 P (Sophist and Philosopher) |\n|-----------------|-------------|-------------------------|---------------------|-------------|---------------------------------|\n| False           | False       | False                   | True                | True        | False                           |\n</truth_table>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (B).\n</answer>\n</EXAMPLE 2>\n\n<EXAMPLE 3>\n<premises>\nWilliam Dickinson was a British politician who sat in the House of Commons William Dickinson attended Westminster school for high school and then the University of Edinburgh. \nThe University of Edinburgh is a university located in the United Kingdom. \nWilliam Dickinson supported the Portland Whigs. \nPeople who supported the Portland Whigs did not get a seat in the Parliament.\n</premises>\n<conclusion>\nWilliam Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university.\n</conclusion>\n<question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? William Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university.\n</question> \n<options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</options>\n<truth_table>\nLet:\n    W: William Dickinson attended Westminster School for high school.\n    E: William Dickinson attended the University of Edinburgh.\n    U: The University of Edinburgh is located in the United Kingdom (Given explicitly, so U = True).\n    L: Westminster School is located in the United Kingdom (Not explicitly stated; uncertain).\nPremises:\n    William Dickinson attended Westminster School for high school and then the University of Edinburgh.\n    The University of Edinburgh is a university located in the United Kingdom.\n    William Dickinson supported the Portland Whigs.\n    People who supported the Portland Whigs did not get a seat in the Parliament.\nConclusion to Evaluate: \n    William Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university, which translates to L \u2227 U.\nLogical Chain:\n    From (2), we know U = True.\n    However, L is not explicitly given by the premises; although implied by context, it remains uncertain.\n    Therefore, since U = True but L is uncertain, the conjunction L \u2227 U is uncertain.\nTruth Table (Key Possibilities):\n| L (Westminster School in UK) | U (University of Edinburgh in UK) | L \u2227 U (Both in UK) |\n|------------------------------|------------------------------------|--------------------|\n| True                         | True                               | True               |\n| False                        | True                               | False              |\n</truth_table>\n<answer>\nThe final answer is (C).\n</answer>\n</EXAMPLE 3>\n\n\nThe following is the problem you need to solve.\n\n<premises>\nAilton Silva, born in 1995, is commonly known as Ailton.\nAilton is a football player who was loaned out to Braga.\nAilton Silva is a Brazilian footballer who plays for N\u00e1utico.\nN\u00e1utico is a football club along with Braga.\nFluminense is a football club.\n</premises>\n<conclusion>\nAilton Silva was loaned out to a football club.\n</conclusion>\n<question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? Ailton Silva was loaned out to a football club.\n</question>\n<options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</options>\n<truth_table>\n"
            }
        ]
    }
]
